Līlāvaī by Koūhala, reedited and translated by Andrew Ollett

This file is in devanāgarī. View in transliteration.

Three sections of the Līlāvaī of Koūhala follow. The first is part of the text’s introduction (20–42), wherein the author gives a short account of his family and explains how he came to tell the story to his wife. The second part (165–234) is a selection from one of the many emboxed narratives in the Līlāvaī: Vijayānanda, who serves as the military commander of the story’s hero, king Sātavāhana, tells the king what happened to him after he was sent on a military expedition to Siṃhala. In this passage, one of the story’s important locales is introduced: the Sapta-godāvarī Bhīma, a shrine to Śiva where the Godāvarī river splits into seven streams before it flows into the Bay of Bengal. The final passage (1008–1101) begins with king Sātavāhana’s trip to the underworld in search of magic powers, and ends just before the king sets out on his final expedition to find the story’s heroine, Līlāvatī.
The text and translation are presented in block. Notes to the text appear when the mouse moves over the asterisk at the end of a verse. Notes to the translation are shown when the mouse moves over an asterisk in the translation. This HTML version also displays variant readings to the text, which are displayed on mouseover. The sigla are:
  • ed: Upadhye’s edition (revised 1966).
  • P: variants reported from P in Upadhye’s edition. P is a transcript of *P, a palm-leaf MS in the Saṃghavī Pāḍā Bhaṇḍāra, Pattan (see Dalal's Descriptive Catalogue of Manuscripts in the Jaina Bhaṇḍāras at Pattan, vol. I, GOS No. 76 (pg. 57 intro) and No. 316 (pg. 193). 131 leaves, both sides, 14" x 2", Devanāgarī (paḍimātrās), with marginal notes, first five leaves damaged on one side. Judged by Śrī Jinavijayaji to be no later than the end of the 13th c. VS.
  • J: variants reported from J in Upadhye’s edition. J is a transcript of *J, a palm-leaf MS in the Big Bhaṇḍāra (= Jinabhadra Sūri Grantha Bhaṇḍāra), Jaisalmer, No. 237 (see A Catalogue of Manuscripts in the Jain Bhandars at Jesalmere, compiled by C. D. Dalal, Baroda 1923). 143 leaves, 12" x 2", Devanāgarī (paḍimātrās), dated samvat 1265, pauṣasudi, dvādaśyām śanau (1208 CE).
  • B: variants reported from B in Upadhye’s edition. B is a transcript of *B, a paper MS in Anūpa Sanskrit Library in Bikaner, no. 3281, 89 folios, 10 1/4" x 4 1/4", Devanāgarī (paḍimātrās used "here and there"), 11-16 lines per page, 40-55 letters per line, missing folios 51 to 70; contains a Sanskrit commentary (dated between Hemacandra's death, 1172 CE, and the copy) dated 1404 CE. B has a number of errors, including especially Sanskritized forms.
  • K: variants reported from K in Upadhye’s edition. K is an article on the Līlāvaī by Ramakrishna Kavi in the Telugu monthly Bhāratī, vol. III, part i, February 1926. I have not personally seen this article.
  • N: digital images of Microfilm A39/10 of the Nepalese-German Manuscript Cataloguing Project (Līlāvaīkahā). The manuscript is 83 folios, 31.0cm x 5.0cm, palm-leaf, incomplete, damaged, Devanāgarī, NAK accession no. 1/1697. ID no. 59612.
As noted in the cover letter, this edition follows the orthography of N, but not necessarily its substantive readings. All of the readings that depart from Upadhye’s edition are noted, and any that affect the sense of the text are also discussed in the notes to the text.

Text

Table of contents

Maṅgala verses (1-19)

Introduction (20-44)

The scene at Pratishthana (45–153)

Vijayananda’s Story (154-280)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: The birth of Mahanumati (281–338)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: Mahanumati meets Madhavanila (339–443)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: The sunset (444–465)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: Kuvalayavali confronts Mahanumati (466–509)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: Madhavilata Arrives (510–523)

Madhavilata’s Story: The Sunset (524–536)

Madhavilata’s Story: The Prince in Longing (537–560)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: A Message for Madhavanila (561–587)

Kuvalayavali’s Story: Kuvalayavali’s Story (588–641)

The expedition to the underworld (1008–1101)

Maṅgala verses (1-19)

May they protect you, the luminous jewels on the hoods of Shesha, on Hari’s ocean bed: they look like shoots budding from the Kaustubha gem, covered by the breasts of Shri.5
[महुमह-वलणुप्पीडिअ-सेस-भुअंगेण मुक्क-फुक्कारा । पवणाऊरिअ-जलअर-सुत्त-विबुद्धो हरी जअउ ॥ ६]1

He plunged his steely arm, elbow-deep, into the maw of the colt-demon Keshin, then expanded his firm hand and, lifting it up, tortured him—victory to the Slayer of Madhu!*
Krishna.

Shiva.

Reverence to the foot of Gauri, rising up to smash the skull-bones of the buffalo-demon who was overcome by its massive weight, its anklets polished by the bowing heads of gods and demons.

Victory to him who created good people as well as wicked people in this world: without darkness, the moon’s rays would prevail over nothing.

Even if they associate with good people, the wicked’s impurity does not abate: though located in the middle of the moon’s orb, the spot remains black.
[दुज्जण-संगेण वि सज्जणस्स णासं ण

[Even if he associates with wicked people, the good man’s conduct is not ruined: as lovely ⁝ salty as a woman’s face is, her lips still flow with sweet nectar.]

Let’s say, rather, that everyone is a good person. In the whole world, no fault can be descried. So listen to what I have to say.8

Introduction (20-44)

 अप्पा ॥ २३
तस्स तणएण एअं
अं N] यं ed
 असार-मइणा वि विरइअं
अं] यं ed, N
 सुणह । कोऊहलेण लीलावइ त्ति
] N
णा
णा Ned] ना PJB
मं कहा-रअ
अ N] य ed
णं ॥ २४
There was once a man who delighted the thirty gods through his devotion to the three holy Vedas and the three sacred fires. He achieved the three aims of life. His name was Bahuladitya.9 The wafting plumes of smoke from his sacrificial fires left a sooty mark on the surface of the moon—the deer-shaped spot that it bears to this day. This man, an ocean of jewel-like virtues, had one son. Bhushanabhatta was his name, and he was the moon in his family’s sky. The Vedas, which first came from Brahma’s four mouths, took their place in his single lotus-mouth, and honored him like a kinsman. Listen to this jewel of a story, called Lilavati, that his son Kautuhala composed, slow-witted as he is.
तं जह मिअं
अं N] यं Bed
क
क Ned] ग B
-केसरि-कर-पहरण
ण ed] om. NP
-दलिअ
अ N] य Ped
-तिमिर-करि-कुंभे
भे ed] भ N
 । वि
वि] (N reads वि before the daṇḍa. N
क्खि
क्खि Ned] च्छि B
त्त-रिक्ख-मुत्ता
] N
हलुज्जले सरअ
अ] य ed
-रअ
अ] य ed
णीए ॥ २५
पओ
ओ ed] उ B
स-समए

मंग-सअ

ण-सुहासीणाए

 भणिअं
अं N] यं ed, ओ सो णियपिययमाए B
 । पिअअम
पिअअम N] पिययम Jed, P has पिययम twice.
 पेच्छ
पेच्छ Ned] पिच्छ B
 पेच्छ
पेच्छ] om. B
 ।
It goes like this. In the twilight of an autumn night, when the lion that is the moon had with its rays10 split the temples of the elephant that is the darkness, lit up by the stars that are its scattered pearls of rut,11 my beloved was relaxing on the terrace of our house. She said to me:
“Look, my dear!
जोण्हा
जोण्हा Ned] जुन्हा B
ऊरिअ
अ N] य ed
-कोस-कंति-धवले सव्वंग-गंधु

क्कडे

ग्घं घर-दीहिआऎ

छ ed] च्छ N
प्पओ ॥ २६
“The moonlight lights up the filaments of a night-lotus in our pond: it’s a lovely white, and its fragrance rich and strong. A bee, buzzing beautifully, is bumbling all around and now he’s stopping on it, encircled by petals just opening up, to savor the liquor of its nectar, abundant and full of rasa.12

अं N] यं ed

अ] य ed
इ व रयणी-मुहं चंदो ॥३३
“The autumn makes the moon all the more beautiful, the moon the night, the night this bed of lotuses, this bed of lotuses the bank, and the bank these geese. Listen to the geese: with their voices softened by the bitter stalks of young lotuses, their calls are like the jingling bangles around the ankles of the goddess of Autumn. A breeze is blowing past, carrying mist from waves of cool water, and thick with the fragrance of fresh jasmine buds mid-blossom. And there on the riverbank is an arcade of trees, swaying in restless waves—henna decorations, as it were, on the cheeks of the girls of the ten directions.13 Do you see these cakravāka birds? Their hearts set on welcoming the day, they are trying to come together in the waters to free themselves from the pain of separation.14 Look at how these bees are captivated by the smell of the blossoming saptaparṇa tree, and wander off without even a thought for the fragrance of other flowers. It’s as if the moon was kissing the night, lotuses tied into her hair, the scent of water lilies hanging in the air, her eyes bright like the stars.
ता किं ब
ब ed] व N

 ॥३५
“Why should I go on? It’s a beautiful autumn night, you have no work to do, and with our servants around, I’d say there’s nothing we’re missing. So let’s have some pleasant entertainment for the evening. Tell me a story, full of rasa and pleasing to women, in your charming voice.”

सुएण सद्द-सत्थेण । उल्लविउं

पु ed] सु N
ण विअ
अ N] य ed
डो कहा-बं
बं ed] व N
धो ॥ ४०
When I heard those words come from her lotus-mouth, I said:
“My lily-eyed love,15 poets have here distinguished three kinds of stories: ‘divine,’ ‘divine-human,’ and just ‘human.’ Earlier poets have laid down rules for each of them, or so I hear.16 And further, famous poets recite various kinds of stories in the beautiful sounds of Sanskrit, Prakrit, or a mixture of the two. I’m not so clever as them. The stories that I could tell would hardly meet with anyone’s approval. What is it, then? Are you trying to humiliate me, dear, for not learning the arts of language? I can hardly speak. Do you think I could tell a story that goes on and on?”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च पिअअमाए
पिअअमाए] पिययमाए ed, om. N, पियमाए J

यअम N] ययम ed, पियम्ह J

-सत्थेण । जेण सुहासिअ

ण

सु कहं ed] om. N
 दिव्व-माणुसिअं
अं] अ N, यं ed
] N
 ॥ ४३
My beloved said:
“My love, who needs the ‘arts of language’? All they do is block the path to enjoyment for people like me. In the end, language is just what reveals a meaning clearly, without troubling the heart. Who needs rules? That’s why you should tell a story in the Prakrit language, one that can hold a girl’s interest—a story of the ‘divine-human’ type, with only a few regional words thrown in.”
तं तह सोऊण पुणो भणिअं
अं] यं ed
 उब्बिंब
उब्बिंब] उव्विंव PJB
-बाल-हरिणच्छि ।
] N
जइ एवं ता सुव्वउ सुसंधि-बं
बं ed] व N
धं कहा-
] N
वत्थुं
वत्थुं ed] रयणं B
 ॥ ४४
On hearing this, I replied: “My dear, with your darting fawn-like eyes—if you insist, listen to this story. It has all of the right elements.”


The scene at Pratishthana (45–153)

णं ed] ण JN
 ॥ ५०
There is on the blessed earth, /whose beautiful hips the four oceans encircle as a belt, whose realms rest stable on Shesha’s coils, who owed her solemnity to the bliss she attained when the boar raised her up from the ocean’s depths at the end of the world, and her weight to all of the gems that adorned her,17 a famous land called Ashmaka, where farmers rejoice all together in the spectacular wealth of their harvest, where the lowing of cows in villages of pleasant lodging carried to the horizons,18 where joyful people gathered to drink and to sing carcarī-songs19 that filled the open spaces, where all pleasures reside, a place which had not left the golden age,20 which was like dharma in physical form, like the creator’s template,21 where good deeds are at home, like a lesson in religious merit, like the source of copious pleasures, like the reflection of good conduct, like an ever-fertile field for the seeds of virtue.
अवि अ
अ] य ed, च N
 ।
सुस
स ed] सि B, सु N

 अपरि

-णि

वासो
सो PJNed] सु B
 त्ति ।
What’s more, it is a place where the cattle are well-fed on soft grass and their cowherds rejoice at the sight, where the sky is filled with the sound of singing mixed with that of so many lutes and pipes,22 where the clear ponds are pleasant to bathe in, where young trees grow dense in beautiful gardens, where every line of sight falls upon a lotus-pond, where at the feet of trees bent down with luscious fruit travellers sleep, where there is not even a suspicion of any trouble, where the four social orders are observed,23 where joy overflows in constant celebration, where groves adorn every plot of land, where the fragrance of all kinds of flowers perfumes the whole sky, where the present age of wickedness24 has yet to set in, where no sin is seen, where people do not abandon their duties, where people have never seen enemy forces, where beauty is undiminished, where the fear of thieves—and kings—has never arisen, where limitless virtues reside.
जहिं च
जहिं च Ned] double daṇḍa before and after B
] N
 । काम-वरिसी भअ
अ] य ed

 त्ति
त्ति] om. B, त्ति ॥ ४० ॥ J, त्ति (cross symbol) N
 । जहिं च
जहिं च ed] om. P
 ।
It is a place where the cloud-god rains whenever it’s wished for, where cows give milk whenever it’s wished for, where trees always bear fruit, where women are never barren.
जहिं च ।
जहिं च । Ned] om. P

मर-वहूहिं । रक्खि

हिं
हिं Bed] हि N
 ॥५३
There, the rivers—deep and coursing strong, flowing over the soft lotus-stalks, their waters always sweet—resemble the women, their breasts large and heavy, their arms soft as lotus-stalks, their voices always sweet.25 Farmer’s wives enchant the deer with their captivating song and thus keep them away from not only their own fields, but their neighbors’ as well.

ण किं पि वो

] N
च्छामि णिसुणेसु ॥ ५५
Within such a wonderful country, my love, there lies a beautiful city, the abode of all pleasures, named Pratishtana. It would take all night to just describe that excellent city, so listen and I’ll tell you something short.
जत्थ वर-का
र-का ed] करा N
मिणी-चलण-णेउरारावम

सलअं

 राअ
अ N] य ed
हंसेहिं ॥ ५६
It’s a place where royal geese drop the lotus-stalks from their mouths to call out in imitation of the sound of the bracelets around the ankles of beautiful women;
जण्ण

where pet peacocks dance on moonstone-paved26 terraces craning to look at the smoke-blackened sky,27

where women with midnight appointments take off their shining jewelry only to find their cover of darkness retreating from the bright rays of jewel-lamps;28

where the wafting fragrances of the garden are so thick with the sweat of women exhausted by merciless lovemaking that nostrils could drink them in,

where geese who crave lotus-fibers are drawn to the circles of moonlight projected on the cheeks of women asleep on the roof,

where the women of Maharashtra wash away their impurity in the Godavari river and dye its waters brown with the turmeric on their breasts.29

डलेण । मइ

] N
ण-वसेण घर-चित्त-भित्तीओ
चित्त-भित्तीओ ed] भित्तिचित्ताइं B, चित्तिभित्तीओ N
 ॥ ६६
There is nothing wrong with that place—except, perhaps, that the fragrance of jasmine on a summer denies women the pleasure of their lovers’ placations.30 [or except, perhaps, that the houses’ crystal walls allow bystanders to see the evidence of lovemaking on the women inside,] or except, perhaps, that the wind blows the pollen of blossoming flowers onto the painted walls of the houses.
तत्थेरिसम्मि
रिसम्मि ed] रिसए B, णिसए N
 णअ
अ N] य ed
रे णीसेस-गुणावगूहिअ

-सरीरो । भुवण-पवि
पवि ed] पिव N
त्थरिअ
अ N] य ed
-ज
ज ed] om. N
सो राआ
आ N] या ed
 सालाहणो णाम ॥ ६७
In that city there is a king who perfectly embodies every virtue, whose fame spreads across the earth, named Satavahana.31
जो सो अ

सूरो वि ण सत्तासो सोमो वि कलंक
क Ned] कि J
-व

ज्जिओ णिच्चं
च्चं ed] व्वं N
 । भोई
ई ed] इ N
 वि ण दोजीहो तुंगो वि समीव-दिण्ण
ण्ण ed] न्न B, ण N
-फ
फ ed] ह B, क N
लो ॥ ७०
He is handsome, beautiful in every last detail, although formless; he brings joy to the people’s eyes, although terrible to look upon.32 He is the favorite of his wives, although a bad husband; he is forceful, although his enemies had submitted; he delights in acts of heroism, although he fears the world beyond.33 He is the sun without his seven horses—a fearless man of courage; the moon without his spot—a spotless man of celebrity; a serpent without a split tongue—an honest man of wealth; a lofty tree with low-hanging fruit—a noble man, beneficent to those around him.34
बहुलंत
बहुलंत ed] बलंत B, वहुलंतु N
-दिणेसु

-विहव

स्स । कुसु

मसराउह-दूओ
उह-दूओ ed] ओह हओ N
] N
 व्व आगओ
आगओ] उवपउ B
 सुअ
अ] य ed
णु महु-मासो ॥ ७६
As the moon becomes wretchedly thin in its first phase, its full disc enveloped in darkness, so he made his enemies wretchedly weak, cut off from their spheres of power. Like the moon, its disc lit up with light, and never passed by the earth, no-one on earth has ever seen his back: for he has conquered the whole world, and his own realms are illuminated by his power.35 His enemies retreated to caves, where they spent their nights in the red luminescence of mountain-plants, as if they had been consumed by the fiery brilliance of his might.36 With their fingers reddened by rays from their fingernails, his favorite wives paint him on the walls of his palace in the guise of the god of love. Without him, the works of even the best poets, thoughtfully composed over time, would waste away in their hearts like the desires of the poor.37 When this man, the lord of the earth, was at the height of his power, springtime arrived like a messenger of the god of love.
पत्थाणं
] N
पढमागअ

डलामोओ
] N
 । हिअआइँ सुहं पच्छा

 विसंति

] N
 सेसा
सा ed] सेमा N
 वि कुसु
सु ed] शु N
म-सरा ॥ ८३
The forests seem to herald the march of spring, already suggested by the first appearance of the southern breeze, with the loud sound of cuckoos on the wing. [With a cluster of mango-blossoms, the wandering parrot seems like a herald: run off, king of winter, for spring now holds the earth.] In a single step, spring’s beauty came to all the flowers of the forest—those that were budding and those that had already budded, those that had blossomed and those that were just now budding. The god of love has so many arrows—what for? Won’t a single shoot of mango do the job?38 Spring takes the karṇikāra fields and seems to wear them like a golden ornament on his forehead, augmenting their beauty.39 If the wafting scent of jasmine can make the tall trees of the arcades burst into bloom, is there anything it can’t do? The pāṭala first softens lovers’ hearts with its fragrance, then its flower-arrows enter with ease.

रेहिँ

 लद्ध-पसरेहिँ
लद्ध-पसरेहिँ ed] लद्ध-पसरेहिं P, लद्ध-प्पसरेहि B, om. N
 कामि-अ
अ N] य ed
णो
णो ed] णे N
 ॥ ९२
Clusters of fragrant blossoming mango-flowers cover the trees so completely that travellers can hardly spot the leaves behind them. The bees force upon the petals of the jasmine flowers before their season, and they fall, pale, from their tendrils, succumbing to the grief of separation from the winter. As tiny clusters of berries form and its calyx starts to weaken, the sinduvāra’s flowers fall away in the gentle breeze. When spring comes into view, and the layer of frost has melted away, the lotus seems to smile as its flower-mouth opens slightly. The branches, with new shoots for hands, dance with delight on the arrival of the southern breeze, and seem to beckon at the Beauty of Spring. In the rows of palāśa trees, the full-blossomed flowers seem to clothe Spring in red garments like a groom on his wedding-day.40 As he fills the mango groves, enters bowers of new mādhavī shoots, and rolls around on leaves of aśoka trees, Spring seems truly delighted.
The breeze, carrying the fragrance of all kinds of plants, touches the delicate shoot of the mango-tree, and she turns away, as if crying flower-tears.41 The forest is in full bloom, and in its midst stands the god of love, bringing lovers under his power by raining flower-arrows down on them.
इ
इ Ned] ई J
अ

 असिअमुहीहिं

16 ॥ ९५
When Love’s arrows had thus conquered the whole world of living beings, the king came to the place where Springtime Beauty arranges her trysts—his court.42 Accompanied by the victory-songs of bards, he seated himself on the lion-throne, which was lit up by rays of light from the jewels on the crowns of hundreds of vassals who had come there to serve him. He was surrounded by his consorts, whose faces always blossomed with smiles, like Indra by celestial women and like the golden mountain by the girls of the directions.43

ण ed] om. N

डणुप्पण्ण

] N
 पाइआ
आ] या ed
 सप्पिणी छीरं ॥ १०४
Then, with a broad smile, the lord of men spoke these charming words to one of them, named Chandralekha.
“Here, Chandralekha. Don’t you see? The whole sky is filled with pollen carried by the southern breezes, as if the god of love has turned it into his bedroom.44 So why is it that today someone thought himself equal to the love-god’s arrows and carefully decorated you from head to toe?45 Who painted on your face this lifelike bee, which seems to press its own face into a fresh campaka flower, eager to drink its nectar? Who used costly musk-paste to paint these designs on your cheeks, which seem like the paths of the love-god’s arrows?46 When did he create this cluster of mango buds at the edge of your cheek, which seems to bring forth flowers at the touch of your hand? Who is it, beautiful girl, who had the privilege of drawing this design on your breasts, which have the color of solid gold?47 Who painted on your feet these two pairs of geese, who are craning their necks to place lotus-stalks in each other’s beaks? Who was it? Someone, surely, who only had the intention of showing off his own skill, without considering whether it is right or wrong—the king of person who would try to feed milk to a snake.”
तं तह सो
सो ed] मो N
ऊण णराहिवाहि
णराहिवाहि ed] 5 written above ॰हि to indicate abl. P, नरविहाउ B, णराहि N

 ॥ १०७
When she heard what the king said, Chandralekha’s eyes lit up, and turning her face down slightly out of modesty, she replied:
“King, there is a painter—a specialist in the realist style—who once drew you on a leaf while he was at the gate of your palace.48 He has just now come back here from the island of Sinhala. He painted all of this during the Spring festival.”49

अम्हं ed] अन्हा B
 ॥ ११२]21
Afterwards, while the king was enjoying himself in a public discussion, the son of one of his ministers found the opportunity to say to him:50
“King, I suspect that man is a spy sent by the king of Sinhala. He has made his way into Chandralekha’s by means of his artistic skills. These kinds of spies, who reside in royal courts in this way,51 are popularly known by the name of Yakshas.”52
[Then, my dear, the king replied: “Vijayananda, together with the capable minister Pottisa, have been dispatched to the king of Sinhala.] [Nobody has come back from his court yet to tell me the truth about what the king of Sinhala says, or what my own commander says.”]
अज्जं चिअ

णंदेण समं महाहवं महइ

 णिक्कंपो ॥ ११५
“Just today our spies have said that Vijayananda and Pottisa have reached the ocean’s shore with a large army. The king of Sinhala, for his part, began his preparations on that very day. He filled his forts with grain and fuel in high spirits. He created obstacles on the seashore and sought out locations for fighting. He is fearless and eager for a great battle with Vijayananda.”

22-चच्चरी ताव
ताव JBed] ताम्व P, तांम्व N
 वोलेउ ॥ ११८
The king said, “Vijayananda is very experienced in matter of war and peace: it is his concern, not mine. He struck fear into the hearts of other supposedly fearless kings, rulers over large territories.53 Is this king of Sinhala going to make him tremble?” Find another time to tell me the news from our spies. Right now, let’s enjoy this wonderful festival of the god of love.”54
एवं भणिऊण णराहिवेण सव्वाण

द्दो ॥ १२२
After these words, the king gave many gifts to all his courtesans and singers for the spring festival. The king honored all of his supplicants, and once a look of satisfaction appeared on his face, my dear, his household priest55 quietly approached and apprised him. “King, it’s noon. Your bath is ready, and there is a crowd of hungry Brahmins at your door, waiting for their daily allowance.”56 Then the king dismissed the rest of the supplicants and agreed to begin his bath. He processed to the bathing area, where he was regaled with songs of victory by hundreds of singers.

] N
 जर-गओ राअ
अ] य ed
-पुरिसेहिं ॥ १२५
In the meantime, a crowd had gathered in the assembly-hall, filled with courtesans mixed with guards, jesters, and officers.57
The sudden crush of people pushed up against an old guard, who fell on his face and started shouting “Help! I’m done for!” With some difficulty, some of the king’s servants fanned him and lifted him up, as if he were an old bull stuck in the mud.
एत्थंत
त्थंत ed] त्थन्त N
रम्मि

 ।

-तण्णा
तण्णा ed] तण्हा B, त्तण्णा N

] N
ण्णा-वाहिप्पंत-परिअ

णो कह
] N
वि राअ
अ N] य ed
-भवणा
णा JBed] णे PN
हि । पवणासासिअ
अ N] य ed
-हिअ
हिअ] हिय ed, om. N
ओ णिअ
अ] य ed, om. N
आ
आ N] या ed
वासं गओ लोओ ॥ १३१
Elsewhere, people moved very slowly, halting in the crush of each other’s bodies, and tripping over the jewels that their constant jostling had knocked out of their headbands. The large breasts of courtesans, which only their lovers are allowed to enjoy, pressed up against the total strangers who stood next to them. One woman, glistening with sweat in the crush of people, struggled to hold up the girdle that came untied and slipped from her wide hips. Another woman broke her necklace of large pearls—and didn’t even mind, because the tight embrace that snapped it was what her heart had wanted all along. Another had plenty of room, but still took a while to find a place in the crowd: she closed her eyes because of the bees that buzzed around her face, drawn by the fragrance of musk. Thus, amid the secretive chatter of their servants, the people went back to their homes from the royal palace, as the breezes lightened their hearts, amid the secretive chatter of their servants.58
राआ
आ N] या ed
 वि पवज्जंतेहिँ विविह-मंगल-णिहोस-मुह

रइ

ण-पल्लंकं
ल्लंकं ed] ल्लंके J, ण्णके N
 ॥ १३६
For his part, the king enjoyed a long bath with all kinds of herbs, while the bugles blared with auspicious songs and while groups of singers and Brahmins recited, and after honoring all of the gods to their satisfaction, he returned to the palace.
There he gave gifts to the Brahmins, including cows, land, gold, vestments, and provisions. From there he went to the dining hall. Over delicious foods of various kinds, each appropriate to the season, he received a stream of the day’s petitioners in a gracious manner. After eating, another group of servants accompanied him to his private chamber, where there was a couch made with choice jewels.
तत्थासी
सी ed] om. N
णो सहिएहिँ सुकइ-छं

 विण्णत्तो

 ॥ १३८
The king was sitting there with his courtiers, poets, and servants, happy and content, when at that moment his doorkeeper, who knew his master’s heart well, came with his staff in his left hand and his right hand covering his eyes, and told him:

णीसेस-णीइ

अ] य ed, वि B
 क
] N
हमागओ एत्थ
एत्थ Ned] इत्थं B
 ॥ १४२26
[ण य भिच्चा णेह करी ण य तुरया णेय पोट्टिसो मंती । विजयाणंदस्स कहं कह जाया एरिसावत्था ॥ १४३]27
“King, for some reason your general Vijayananda has returned from the campaign and is waiting at your door, clothed in tattered rags.”
As soon as the heard this, the lord of the earth felt a shock of disappointment. He fixed his gaze on his minister’s face and said to him: “Bhatta Kumarila! Did you hear what the doorkeeper said? Why is Vijayananda in such a state? He holds in his mind the vast expanse of all of the principles of statecraft. So how could it be that he has come back here alone and on foot? [He has no servants with him, no elephants or horses. And where is the minister Pottisa? How in the world could Vijayananda have reached such a state?]”
भणिअं
अं] यं ed, अं च N
 भट्ट-कुमारे रिले

च्छा ed] त्था N
आ
आ N] या ed
 ॥ १४७
“King,” said Bhatta Kumarila, “sometimes events take a turn for the worse. If you were to ask me, however, there must be a good reason why he has come back. Why do I say so? Men whose masters have honored them by entrusting them with such monumental tasks prefer death if they cannot accomplish them. So, if in fact he met defeat at the hands of the king of Sinhala, he would certainly not show up at your door alive.”
“Well,” said the king, “there is no point in speculation. He himself can throw some light on what happened. Bring him in without delay, so that I can see his face.”

 पहुणा ॥ १५०
Then the king gave the doorkeeper the sign, and he returned with Vijayananda behind him. As the king looked upon him, he bowed his head to the ground. The king approached him, my dear, and bade him to make himself comfortable. When he sat down, his eyes did not stray from Bhatta Kumarila’s feet.5960 Then, once the king had gotten him to sit down and told everyone else to leave, he comforted Vijayananda for a moment and asked him earnestly:
हं

हो तुह विजआ

-हिअआ
हिअआ] हियया ed, om. N
 णिसामेह ॥ १५३
“Vijayananda, seeing you come here like this breaks my heart, especially because you came without any explanation.”
When he heard these words of sympathy from his master, his eyes opened wide with delight, and he responded: “King, it’s really a long story, full of wishes that remain unfulfilled.61 I’ll do my best to tell it, and you should give it your full attention.”


Vijayananda’s Story (154-280)

अ N] य ed
-परिवार-परिअ
अ N] य ed
रिओ ॥ १७१
Once I had brought the king of Malaya62 under my power, and conquered the Pandya king,63 I started my preparations to cross over to the far shore of the ocean, the minister Shri Pottisa said: “First of all, stop what you’re doing: we’re not going to overcome Shilamegha so easily by force. Even a common enemy can hardly be defeated in open battle if he’s built fortifications. But he’s no common enemy. He is lucky, brave, generous, and has loyal servants. He is reasonable and virtuous, unconquered by enemy forces, and proud. He values counsel and exertion above all. It would be difficult for such a man’s enemies to triumph. For all rulers, the earth must be won through both policy and valor. Men who are only concerned with valor never enjoy true success. But if one can practice conciliation, if he knows how to sow dissent, and if he has resources for bribery, he doesn’t even need to consider force. Success chooses as her own those men who act according to the principles laid down by earlier teachers in the texts on polity.64 So send a messenger who’s a skilled talker, an expert in diplomacy, who knows well the hearts of others, who is skilled and resolute and mindful of the time. If that man can win him over, then tell me, what’s the point of all these efforts? Should you waste poison on a man who can be undone by words? I have heard, too, that he has a daughter named Lilavati, dearer to him than life, the essence of the whole world of living beings. When she was born, a god communicated in an incorporeal voice, which the fortune-tellers interpreted, that the man whom this beautiful girl chooses as her husband, when the time comes, will rule the whole earth and obtain supernatural powers. So if he can somehow win over this jewel of a princess for our master, then we’ll have accomplished everything there is to do on this earth. What’s more, that king already thinks that our master would be a fitting recipient for jewels of this kind, so a policy of concilation towards him seems best.”
When I heard everything that the minister Pottisa had to say, I replied: “Forget about sending a messenger. I’ll go myself! If I can get an audience with him and win him over with affection and respect, he’ll give over that jewel of a princess to my master on the spot.”
Shri Pottisa again spoke: “With something like this at stake, I cannot oppose your going to the king of Sinhala yourself.”
Thus, after taking counsel with him several more times, great lord,65 I departed from the camp at dawn, accompanied by a select group of men.
तो तं सिरि-कुल-भ

उलोल्लो ed] उलो J
] N
लो ॥ १७५
Then I quickly reached the ocean—the ocean, where Lakshmi lives, where Vishnu sleeps, where the women of the horizons are stationed. It was like a moat built around the world, like a mirror-image of the expansive sky, like a skirt over the earth’s hips, like the darkness stored up for the final annihilation, like the birthplace of the worlds. When I saw that ocean, lord, my heart sank. Pottisa was right: it would be nearly impossible to cross. It seemed to fill the furthest reaches of the sky with the howling of its fierce winds, and it heaved constantly with the gathering and breaking of its immense waves.
णिं
णिं ed] णि N
तच्छ

 सवाणिओ च्चेअ
च्चेअ] च्चेव ed, चेव P, च्चेव JB, चेअ N
 ॥ १७७
If the heavenly nymphs had emerged from it, could beautiful women still overrun it? If cosmic poison had been extracted from it, could it still be full of poison? If the elephant Airavana and the horse Uccaihshravas left it long ago, could it still protect the great king Indra?66 The ocean was swaying drunkenly even though its liquor had long been removed. And though drunk, it never transgressed its limits. It was tasteless despite keeping within its boundaries. And despite being tasteless, it was in fact full of briny water.67

ण-वत्तं

 समारू
मारू ed] मत्ते N
ढो ॥ १८३
At the ocean’s shore, the enormous bridge tells the story of Rama to this day: it’s like the hand of the southern mountains, pointing out the valor of the monkey king.68 There the sloping shores look as if the waves had thrown jewels from the depths of the sea up onto the brush, like flowers of worship strewn before the house-temple of Lakshmi. Kesara plants fill the air with the fragrance of their flower-clusters blossoming on the shore: to this day, they tell of how liquor was once extracted from the ocean. The saptaparṇa trees, their branches weighed down with thick bands of buzzing bees, mark out to this day the path of the Airavana elephant produced by churning the ocean.69 There, in their huts made from tender sandalwood saplings, the siddha couples enjoyed the wind, suffused with the fragrance of groves of clove and cardamom.70 There I bowed to Rameshwara, where millions of gods and demons have worn down the pedestal with the crowns of their bowed heads, and boarded my vessel.71

घडिओ असमंजस-कज्ज-बं

 व्व
व्व ed] व N
 ॥ १८८
What can be well-born in a bad family? What moves legless on nimble feet? What is rich in virtue but poorly thought of? What has many affairs but no affection? That ship: for it was not bound to the land, it was well-covered, it had no legs, it moved adroitly over the water, it had many ropes, it was swift, it led us through the sea, and it brought together many people.72 I picked the men to accompany me and I boarded the ship. But before we had crossed the ocean, king, all of a sudden a storm broke out, ripping out trees on the shore, filling the sky as far as the eye could see, and washing out the eastern islands. Our boat was tossed on the wind-frenzied waves all the way to the Godavari river delta in the eastern sea. There the ship’s hull was smashed on the shore’s rugged rocks, and it broke into hundreds of pieces, like a poorly-laid plan come to ruin.
भिण्णम्मि
ण्णम्मि ed] ण्णंमि N
 तम्मि
तम्मि ed] तंमि N

 ॥ १९०
When the ship was destroyed, the crew brought me to the mouth of the Godavari river, clinging to a single plank. The surges of the briny sea tossed my limp body ashore, and I asked the crew who was still alive.

 ॥ १९३
With their faces downturned in despair, they reluctantly told me:
“Prince, death has swallowed up your companions. Nothing can be done. In this world, cruel fate strikes not only the wicked with disaster, but even noble men such as yourself. You have to press on. Just like the new moon always gets back its former splendor, those who emerge from disaster alive can easily get back their former eminence.”

त्तणमुवॆं
वॆं ed] वि N
ति ॥ २००
That, king, was the report I heard from them, unbearable as a lightning bolt. Only with great difficulty could I turn myself back from the jaws of death. My heart sank. My companions were gone, and my task had come to ruin. Nor did I have my master’s approval, or my own reputation, to console me. Even more than the pain of losing my closest friends, my heart grieved for the failure of the task that it had so earnestly hoped to accomplish. There are few people who are up to the task, who vigorously follow what they’ve started to completion, who can just pick up their burden and lift it up high. I’m not like them at all. I have no wisdom, no courage, no skill, and no luck. How is someone like me supposed to carry out the king’s ambitious plans? Despite these thoughts, as the vicissitudes of life kept flashing before my eyes, I eventually came around to what those sailors said to me. You might ask why, in a moment of crisis, I took the advice of some cowherds from the middle of nowhere. I say: If you’re drowning in a well, you’ll grab onto a clump of grass if you have to.
ता गंतूण स-कडअं
अं] अ N, यं ed
 पुणो वि

हाएहिं । पारद्ध-कज्ज-णिव्वह

ण-णिच्छ
च्छ ed] च्छि J, om. N
ए सज्जिमो अप्पा ॥ २०१
“I need to go back to my camp,” I said. “The rest of my companions and I will ready ourselves to finish the task that we started.”

ईहि
ईहि ed] अइं N
 भावेण सूलहरं ॥ २०९
Thus I pulled myself together, casting off my heart’s despair, and I set off on the road pointed out by the crew. I passed a thicket of trees, draped by the thick fragrance of cardamom, gooseberries, and cloves, and at long last I reached a patch of forest right next to the seashore. Pine and mangosteen, priyāl and sāl trees offered shade from above, and below there were clusters of puṃnāga, nāgakesara, rose-apple, kadamba and mango flowers. The streams of water, coursing toward their seven mouths, wash away all of the impurity of the Kali age: that, my lord, was the Sapta-Godavari Bhima.73 The Godavari, on its way to taste the ocean with its seven mouths, washed away my grief: a true friend will stay with you even when disaster strikes. I bathed in its waters to my heart’s content, and with my strength restored, I proceeded to the temple of Pinakin*
Pinakin: a name of Shiva.
which removes the fear of all the world’s beings. The next instant, I beheld the destroyer of Tripura, Andhaka, the elephant demon, and the body of Love—the husband of Parvati, Shiva, with the diadems of all of the gods and demons piled at his feet.74 With hymns of praise from the sacred texts of Yoga, I praised him sincerely, the one made up of the three cosmic qualities, the three holy Vedas, the three sacred formulas, and the Triad, whose feet are praised by the thirteen gods, who holds the trident.75
अल्लीणो

ओ Ned] यं B
 कुस
स ed] श N
लं ॥ २१३
I happened upon an unusual but charming monastery which could have been the entrance to the next world. In one of its corners a naked Pashupata*
A devotee of Pashupati (Shiva).
 ascetic was seated on a throne. His neck was bent down and quivering with the burden of his gray dreadlocks. Decrepitude had overtaken his limbs, driving out the beauty of youth. His body was covered with cloud-white ashes, and he wore a string of rudrākṣa beads.76 I paid him reverence, and he invited me to sit down on a wicker stool. Once I had taken my place next to him, he asked after my health.
कत्तोहिंतो
हिंतो ed] हित्तो N

चिंति ed] चित्त N

अं N] यं ed

अ N] य ed
वं सुतित्थ
] N
-जत्ता-पसंगे
] N
ण ॥ २१४
“Where have you come from?” he said. “What made you decide to come here?”
“Blessed one,” I said, “I wanted to make a pilgrimage to this holy place.”

अ N] य ed
रं ब
ब ed] व N
हुसो ॥ २१६
Soon I found myself discussing religious and philosophical topics with him at length. He showed me such kindness as I would have expected from an old friend. We talked until the lord of the day77 had travelled halfway through the expanse of the sky. Then the great sage addressed me with respect:
एत्थ
त्थ Ned] त्थं J
म्हे
म्हे Jed] मे N

ऊण । आणेमि

भोअणं जं म्ह] भोयणं जं म्ह ed, भोयणं जम्ह P, जं म्ह भोयणं B, भाअणे जम्ह N
 ॥ २१८
“We’re poor beggars here, wise one. We live on roots and fruits. I’m afraid you won’t find the kind of food you’re used to here. Still, if you just wait a moment, I’ll go and bring you some of the food that’s available. Please excuse me.”

रेण भुंजाविओ तत्थ ॥ २२१
With these words, he went to the base of the nearest tree. There, to my amazement, I saw something I’d never seen before: an unseen forest-goddess, king, filled up his alms-bowl with all kinds of fruits. Nothing is impossible for ascetic power.78 Then, king, carefully attentive to his duties as a host, the sage offered me those delicious fruits to eat.

 सुहं जासि
सि ed] हि N
 ॥ २३१
By then the lord of the day was in the eighth part of the sky. The great sage addressed me again, but this time with foreboding:
“A demon named Bhīṣānana lives in these parts, prince. He suffers no-one to stay here, apart from me. So, as much as I would like to stay with you here in Shiva’s temple, we can’t stay a single night without puṇya.79 Don’t you see that the sun, who alone sees everything that happens in all of the worlds, is speeding his horses towards the western mountain? His rays are falling on the tree-trunks, and the trees seem eager to leave their retreating shadows behind, knowing that there will be nobody to enjoy them at night. In the spaces between patches of forests that encircle them, the mountains are tinted gold, reddened in the twilight glow. The evening chill drives the flocks of buffalo, covered in thick mud, out of the lakes and into the forest. What can compare to the love shared between the sun and the day? From the very beginning, they have never known a moment’s separation from each other. Come now, it’s nothing to get upset about. In this world, you’ll never get your heart’s desire without puṇya, no matter how good you are. So let me suggest something to you. While there is still some daylight left, I will show you to a place where you can stay in comfort.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च मए
] N
 भअ
अ] य ed
वं किं
] N
काही सो णिसाअ
अ N] य ed
रो मज्झ
मज्झ Ned] अम्ह B
 । ऎ
ऎ ed] इ B, ए N
त्थ च्चिअ

 परिवसिमो तुम्हेहिँ
हिँ ed] हिं N
 समं जहिच्छा
हिच्छा ed] हिंत्था N
ए ॥ २३२
“Blessed one,” I said, “I will be happy to stay right here with you. What could that demon do to me?”
तो तेण पुणो

संभो । हिअ

इच्छिअं

हिंतो
तो ed] ते N
 ॥ २४१
“Stop talking like that,” he answered. “If you knew what he was really like, wise one, you wouldn’t say such things. The demon has a cohort of ten thousand demon soldiers, sir, and when they come out at night, not even the gods can defeat them. But very close to us here is the hermitage of two girls, the daughters of a Yaksha80 and of a sage. It’s stunning, covered in flowers and vines, and rich in fruit trees. The calls of exotic birds echo through sky, and the sun’s rays shoot through a dense tangle of sprouting trees and vines. One of the girls is named Mahanumati, the daughter of the Yaksha king. I don’t know why she’s staying in that compound for ascetics. The other, named Kuvalayavali, is just as beautiful. She’s the creator’s crowning achievement. She is the daughter of a great sage, and an impressive ascetic in her own right. Their hearts are bound fast by their love for each other: as the days pass, they experience the same pleasures and pains. Let’s go, then. I must show you to them before night blackens the vision of these worn-out eyes, so that you can stay the night there and immediately proceed, fully rested, from the girls’ hermitage to wherever your heart desires.”
अ
] N
ह तेण समं णरवइ संपत्तो तं त

वोवणुज्जाणं । जं

ट्ठ-उव्वं

 भवाणि-भव-भवणमइरम्मं
मइरम्मं ed] यं रम्मं P, अंमइरम् N, मइरम्भं J, अइरम्मं B
 ॥ २४६
Then, king, I went with him to the hermitage. Indra would forget all about heaven if he saw it.
There, I saw an absolutely beautiful temple of Bhavani:*
Parvati, the wife of Shiva (Bhava).
its crystal-clear enclosing walls were tall and shone with hundreds of inlaid jewels; the whole region was full of the fragrance of the flowers of the trees planted around it; a group of śālabhañjikās81 were cut into the beryl pillars of the outer gateway; diamonds, sapphires, and emeralds adorned its main tower; ; all kinds of precious rubies scattered rays of light onto the doorway of the temple; wonderful steps made out of coral formed its entryway; ; Nandi and Mahakala*
Nandi and Mahakala: the two doorkeepers of Shiva.
 took their place in the bull-pavilion82 made of gold and silver. I’ve never seen anything like it.

णं
णं ed] णी N
 ॥ २५०35
The balconies 83 that go out on both sides like outstretched wings, and the pennants fluttering in the wind like feathers, made it seem like it was taking flight. The cooing of the pigeons stepping around just outside of their nests as they try to soothe the anger of their mates made it seem like it was talking. The gusts of wind, made even more wonderful by the cool water from the nearby river, carried lotus petals that made it seem like an offering.
To the south of this golden temple there was a beautiful hermitage, which was like a henna decoration on the face of the Godavari river.

-सिला-वट्टे
ट्टे Bed] ट्ठे P, टे N
 ॥ २५७
In it was a jewel-studded platform, resplendent with colorful arrangements of the pollen of so many flowers, and shaded by a canopy of woody vines,84 where I saw a group of female ascetics sitting, abiding by their vows, as if it was a harem—but with the flower-bowed god of love, incinerated by Shiva’s fire, nowhere to be seen. And in their midst, in the garb of ascetics, I saw two of them sharing the same seat, one the daughter of a Yaksha, and the other of a sage. “She must be Mahanumati,” I thought, “and that one must be Kuvalayavali.” I approached them.
Then, as soon as the two of them saw the hermit, they got up from their seats and took a few steps toward him. They bowed their lotus-heads in reverence to him and, once he was seated, they presented a welcome-offering before his feet.85 I was treated to a similar reception, my lord: when I took my place on a beautiful jewel-studded platform next to them, I had the pleasure of being honored by their words.

तस्स । तं थण-णिहे

ण पुंजीकअं
अं] यं ed

ऍ ed] ण B
 लाअ
अ] य ed
ण्णं ॥ २६२38
King, I am at a loss to describe the two of them. Indra would finally find a use for his thousand eyes.86 The world of the gods would be happy to use their “unblinking gaze” to get a full view of the daughters of the Yaksha and the sage.87 Clad in two bark garments88 which looked like a flood of autumnal moonlight, it seemed that Fame and Prosperity had appeared in one place.89 Since they wore no adornments, they looked like Lakshmi at the moment she emerged from the foam of the ocean at the time of its churning—except doubled.90 It was as if the creator balled up, in the form of their breasts, the loveliness that was left over after creating their other parts.
अह एवं विम्हअ

-झाण
झाण PNed] जाण B, साण J
-ट्ठिआ
आ N] या ed
 तत्थ ॥ २७२
As I sat there in amazement, the hermit began to address the two beautiful ascetic girls: “I have to tell you something. This here is a great ocean, and virtues are his jewels.91 He knows the meanings of all of the sacred texts. His name is Vijayananda. He is a good man, pure, 92 the son of a good Brahmin. He’ll find a spot here for the night, thanks to your kindness, and in the morning he will proceed from here to wherever it is that he wants to go with a happy heart.” “Reverend,” they said, “wherever guests of yours stay, even for a moment, we happily regard as the entire world.”93
The teacher was pleased. He gave his blessing and started on his way back. For my part, I was relieved to take my seat in front of them, abiding by the rules of modesty. Then, king, I conversed with them at length on appropriate topics until the sun set in the western mountains. The peacocks flew up into the tops of the hermitage’s trees, as if they were spies of the darkness sent to see how much of the twilight was left. Mahanumati respectfully spoke to me: “Sir, please listen. It is coming to the time for me to meditate.94 So please make yourself comfortable here, wise sir, and Kuvalayavali will divert you for some time with religious stories.” With those words Mahanumati went inside the meditation room. There she remained in concentration, settling her mental activities with utmost skill.
अह सा मए
ए ed] om. N
 णराहिव विणओ
ओ NJed] उ P, यो B
णअ

] N
-सोहाए । एम्व

-विहं
] N
तव-चरणं एम्व
एम्व Jed] एव PB
-विहो तवोवणो
तवोवणो ed] वोमणा N
 वासो ॥ २७६
At that point, king, I couldn’t help but show what I was thinking. Very politely, I set aside formality and asked the girl about the truth.95 “Sister, I know that it is rude and perhaps disrespectful to our elders for me to already speak in such a rough manner before you, but since I have no sense of this place, my bewildered heart is urging me on.96 So if it wouldn’t trouble you, please tell me: What is this? Such a beautiful girl, at an age of such possibility, practicing such austerities and living in such a hermitage—I just don’t understand.”
तो तं
तो तं NB] एवं ed
41 सोऊण म
म Ned] स B
माहि तक्खणं
णं ed] ण N

हिअ

ण-जलेण । सिप्पं

 । अमुणिअ
अ] य ed
-सील-सहावे जणम्मि किं कह कहि
किं कह कहि ed] किरनेयमि B
ज्जंति ॥ २८० ]45
When she heard me say this, tears immediately welled up in her eyes and started to fall on the bark-dress that covered her breasts. She said: “Brother, why would you even want to hear the horrible tale of us two ill-fated girls, so painful as it is to listen to?”
[After saying this, she said: “Brother, nobody should tell secrets to someone whom they’ve only just met.”]
[“What gives you pleasure and what gives you pain, your virtues and vices, and especially your secrets—would you really tell any of these to someone whose true character you don’t know?”]


Kuvalayavali’s Story: The birth of Mahanumati (281–338)

तह वि ज
] N
इ महसि सोउं ता सुव्वउ अत्थि
त्थि ed] थि N
 तिअ
अ N] य ed
स-सुह-वासो । कुल-महिहराण पढमो मेरु त्ति तिलोअ
अ N] य ed
-विक्खाओ ॥ २८१
If you still want to hear it, then listen.
There is a place where the gods live in peace,
the foremost of the Family Mountains,
known throughout the world as Meru.97
कणअ
अ N] य ed
-सिलाअ

 रवि-तुरंगेहिं ॥ २८२
The horses of the sun encircle it,
struggling restlessly to jump ahead of the chariot
that skates over its golden slopes.

ज्जइ दिग्गइंदेहिं ॥ २८३
There reside the ruddy elephants of the horizon,
who can hardly make each other out
amid the clouds of gold-dust that Shiva’s bull
keeps kicking up with his horns.98
गरुल-णह-कुलिस-विउडि

] N
द्ध-मिहुणेहिं ॥ २८४
There the Siddha couples drink liquor
to their hearts’ content, relaxing
on the golden rock-face that has been scored
by Garuda’s blade-like claws.*
Garuda: Vishnu’s mount, the eagle.

There the Kinnaras, who make their homes in the gardens
where the peacock of the six-faced god*
the six-faced god: Skanda or Karttikeya.
 dances,
enchant the prancing deer with their singing.99

There you could hear Tumbura
improvising a tune to the accompaniment
of the deep Vedic chanting of the seven sages,
with Brahma’s goose providing the harmony.100

There women are always hurrying
to meet their lovers, even as the nectar
of the flowers of the pārijāta tree
in full bloom slows them down.101

The golden lotus only enhance its beauty,
abuzz with bees that stop on their petals, greedy
for the fragrant ichor that flows from the temples
of Indra’s elephant Airavana as he bathes.102

Along the southern ridges of that golden mountain
there is a city named Sulasa, full of riches,
surpassing even the capital city of Indra.

There lived Hamsa, king of the Vidyadharas,

and his dear wife Padma,
who attended all his wishes.103

She was mother to two beautiful daughters.
One of them was named Vasantashri,

The two of them lived happily
because of the kind advice
they got from their parents,
and they passed their days
resolved to worship the gods.

Thus they would always go
before Shiva and Parvati on Mount Kailasa,
gaining access through their skills
in playing the vīṇā.*
vīṇā: a stringed instrument.

Ganesha.

The gems in the hoods of the great serpents cast moving beams of light across his broad chest, and he hummed with the sound of the bees that swarmed him to taste the ichor freely flowing from his temples.106

He was horrifying, throwing up his axe in his erratic movements and then catching it in his sturdy hands, and the white snakes that hung from his ears made his whole face terrific.

His broad forehead was wrapped up in fresh shoots and blossoms of the pārijāta tree, and when his trunk touched the tip of his one tusk, it let out a hiss.

His flapping ears covered over the whole expanse of the sky, and his pounding feet pushed down the mountain and forced all of Shiva’s attendants to the opposite side.

When she saw the lord Ganesha dancing with so much enthusiasm and enjoyment, Sharadashri laughed and said very quietly:
उअ
अ ed] om. N

वि ed] व N
 गुणेण ॥ ३००
“Do you see the way that Ganesha is dancing, with this strange and deformed kind of grace? Even the gods will find any reason to puff themselves up with self-regard.”
तो तेण सोवहासं वअणं
वअणं] वयणं ed, वाते N
 उव
उव ed] ऊअ N

This insulting remark didn’t escape Ganesha, who became enraged and put a cruel curse on Sharadashri.
जह वच्च दुव्विणी

“Go and live in the wicked world of men below,” he said, “where you can reap the fruit of the tree of wanton youth.”

As soon as they heard these awful words from Ganesha, which were irresistible as a bolt of lightning, they addressed him as follows, trembling with fear:

“Lord, honored by the three worlds, do not be angry. Indeed, we are your servants, and they say that there’s nothing wrong with having a laugh with one’s superiors, so long as there’s no malice.

We certainly have no hurtful feelings. People must not ridicule you. Wouldn’t it be useless for you to bear such meanness in your heart?

Who would ridicule you? You who wear snakes as ornaments, who is there in the three worlds who is greater than you, that you should curse girls like us?

Lord Ganesha then addressed the other one: “Doe-eyed girl, do not cry. You will obtain by my grace a boon of your heart’s desire.”

When he heard it, the tears flowed freely from King Hamsa’s eyes as he wept with his daughter. “Oh!” he said, “what the lord has done is not fair.

“Oh! It is because of my mistake that my father bears such a burden of anxiety with a despairing heart, his happiness displaced by a parent’s concern.

Who will laugh? Who will sing? Who will dance? Who will tell the dirty jokes? Without Sharadashri, there would be no enjoyment in this wedding of mine.

Now is the time to get a husband from the boon that the compassionate god Ganesha once offered me.

ब ed] व PN
हुएहिँ मि

 पसाएण ॥ ३३१
Why should I bother with all of these worries? I choose Nalakubara, the son of the lord of wealth!*
lord of wealth: the god Kubera.
 Ganesha, by your grace, make this happen!”
तो सो हेरंब

Then Ganesha’s boon worked its effects, and Hamsa’s face lit up as the son of Kubera suddenly came into his mind.

Then, with the consent of his friends, relatives, and servants, the king of the Vidyadharas gave his daughter to Nalakubara with delight.

His father, the lord of wealth, gladly agreed and accepted her like a garland of flowers.

The next day, Nalakubara quickly reached Sulasa, making the sky beautiful with all of the vehicles that followed behind him.

There, good sir, he celebrated the wedding, amid crowds of gods, Siddhas, Kimnaras, Vidyadharas, Yakshas, and their wives, who were all singing their blessings.

Then, when the wedding was over, he rushed back with even greater speed, with a fleet of vehicles all humming, rattling, and ringing

and reached his home. There, he lived with her to his heart’s content, and they had a daughter—Mahanumati here.


Kuvalayavali’s Story: Mahanumati meets Madhavanila (339–443)

] N
अ
अ N] य ed
मुव्वहइ । ता वच्च
च्च ed] व N
म्ह पहुप्पंति
प्पंति ed] प्पन्ति N
 जेण सव्वा
व्वा Ned] च्चा J
इँ
इँ ed] इं J, इं N
 रमिआइं
रमिआइं] रमियाइं ed, om. N
 ॥ ३४८
You might ask why a girl born in the family of Kubera, in the spring of her youth, is experiencing this enormous grief, which her own conduct could never have allowed. You know, of course, that girls—to whose mouths the scent of milk still clings107—spend their days at their parents’ home, doing whatever appeals to them. Reverence to you, Youth, for you deserve praise in all respects: you stay as you want, wander as you want, rest as you want, and talk as you want! This girl would spend the whole day playing with her friends on the pleasant golden slopes. One day, just before dawn, she told me: “Friend, we have never seen Mount Malaya. Why don’t we go there? There are swings made out of mādhavī vines hung from the tops of the sandalwood trees. We can play with the Siddha girls there and then come back.”
“Friend,” I said, “could there be any place more charming in all respects than the city of Alaka here? I will tell you, friend, that heaven itself cannot compare to the place where we were born, and since birth my sincere affection for this place has only grown, and I enjoy it all the more. Nevertheless, if you want to go to Malaya, surrounded by coastal caves filled with the ocean’s waters, then let’s go there before the sun reddens the eastern sky, so we can play all day.”
तो तोरविअ
अ N] य ed
-विमाणाउ तक्खणं णिय-सही

गमामुक्का । आसण्ण

-61दिणह
ह N] य ed
रोहंस-पाअ
अ N] य ed
वा सिद्ध-मिहुणेहिं ॥ ३५५
At that very moment they took off with all their friends, their vehicles speeding and their hair blowing in the wind of the expanse of the sky, and they reached Mount Malaya, which occupied the whole expanse of the southern sky and which was surrounded by offerings of jewels cast upon the shore of the ocean. With the sun blazing at its base, and its peaks like rolling pillars of dark smoke, it looked like the cosmic conflagration, just after consuming the universe, was right in front of them.108 As the submarine fire109 heated up the ocean, Mount Malaya seemed to be cooling it down, spraying the essence of sandal, camphor, and cloves from its waterfalls. As the stars swirled around its rocky ridges, they took on the appearance of a mist from the streams that cascade from its massive peaks. The rays of the sun couldn’t break into its leafy bowers, as if they stopped short upon hearing the noises coming from the divine Siddha couples within. As the sun alighted on its sandal trees, the intense heat put the serpents who inhabit them to flight, leaving the Siddha couples free to enjoy them.110
अवि अ
अ N] य ed
 ।
सुर

 । सुर

-सिद्ध-सुह-णि

वासं
सं Bed] स PJ, स J
 अच्चंत-मणो
] N
हरं मलअं
अं N] यं ed
 ॥ ३५९
What’s more, the wishing-trees were left bare as soon as they began to blossom, because celestial girls picked and ran off with all their flowers; the coursing wind was pleasantly cool, because it fanned through bowers of sandal trees; its grassy meadows, growing in emerald valleys, could only be seen when they dried up111; its rivulets, running over riverbeds of crystal, could only be known by touching them; sages gathered to perform group sacrifices, cleansed by water from its clouds;112 its peaks interrupted the expanse of the sky to the furthest horizons: such was Mount Malaya, ringed by all kinds of beautiful gardens and bowers of vines, where gods and Siddhas lived, charming beyond measure.
अह तस्स महा-गिरिणो णिअं
अं N] यं ed
ब
ब ed] व N

ह-वास-हरं
हरं ed] हं N
 व मणहरं महिहरुज्जाणं ॥ ३६४
That immense mountain had a wonderful garden that adorned a part of its slopes and filled the sky with the fragrance of the flowers of many kinds of trees.113 It was alive with the calls of the most excellent birds joining the humming of bees, bees humming as they opened up the flower-blossoms with their mouths and perfumed the breeze, the breeze brought a scent that hung over the stands of areca trees that formed an enclosing fence, and atop this enclosing fence were heavy bowers of mango-trees from which were hanging gangs of monkeys, and these gangs of monkeys were breaking open the mango-fruits and raining juice on the base of the tree, and at the base of the tree some girls, while they were out picking flowers, had set up and worshipped an image of the God of Love.114 Such was the mountain’s charming garden, where the sun cast its beams through the soft and tangled vines of all kinds of plants. It was as if the God of Love, and his wife Rati, made it their home.115
तस्स

 उज्जाण-भवणअं
अं N] यं ed

णं Ned] नं PJB
दण-वणं व ॥ ३६९
In the center of the garden there was a temple, its forecourt paved with colorful precious stones. Even the gods would forget about their homes if they saw it. And sitting in the charming courtyard in front of this temple I saw a girl who could have been the garden’s forest-goddess.116 At that moment she was playing the vīṇā,*
vīṇā: a stringed instrument.
 and as she turned her neck and cast her glance upwards, she saw our vehicle stopped midair. Folding her hands and showing her sincerity with a bow, she arose and spoke sweetly but without forgetting her modesty:
“Revered girls, please come down and visit this temple’s garden, which is like the Nandana grove in heaven itself. You will make it even more beautiful with the offerings of your lotus-feet.117”

म्म-वासं
सं ed] स N
 व वर-भवणं ॥ ३७५
Her words pleased us so much that our hearts swelled with friendship and descended even before our vehicle. Then, sir, we took comfortable seats and asked the young woman: “Please tell us, beautiful girl: who are you? Who does this hand belong to, skilled in drawing intricate designs in henna?118 Who do these beautiful lutes we see here belong to, with their lovely notes? Who do these gaming-boards belong to, their surfaces painted with intricate patterns, which hint at mastery of all the fine arts? Who do all these weapons we see here belong to, beautiful girl, smeared with sandal paste and capable of destroying the pride of your enemies? Who does this collection of books we see on the stand119 here belong to, lovely girl? Tell us, who does this excellent temple belong to, which seems like the home of Vishvakarman himself?”*
Vishvakarman: the architect of the gods.
तं तह सोऊण ममाहि

ल्ल-75णअण-वअणाऎ

 । एसो सो
] N
दोल-हरो
] N
 रमह जहिच्छा
च्छा ed] त्था N
ऎ
ऎ N] इ ed
 ता एण्हिं
ण्हिं ed] ण्हि N
 ॥ ३८६
When she heard this, brother, she began talking to me: “Blessed lady,” she said, “listen: I will tell you, if you are interested. Here, above the peaks of Mount Malaya, there is a large and well-fortified town which makes all of the surrounding areas fragrant with the smell of all kinds of plants, where the flirtatious looks upon the lotus-faces of the Siddha women makes the houses beautiful, and which even the gods long for. It is called Kerala.*
Kerala: Mount Malaya represents the Malabar range, which is found in the modern state of Kerala. As a place-name, Kerala goes back at least to the edicts of Ashoka.
 There reigns the king of the Siddhas, famous throughout the three worlds like the king of the gods, whose name is Malayanila,*
Malayanila: literally, “the Breeze of Malaya.”
 whose strength is unsurpassed like Mount Meru.120 His first and dearest wife, who is close to his heart, is called Kamala, and she has just one son, who is called Madhavanila.*
Madhavanila: “the Springtime Breeze.”
 This is his garden and schoolhouse, which the king Malayanila built for him, for his heart is completely given over to affection for his beloved son. My name is Madhavilata, and I am the keeper of his garden. He and I played in the same dirt ever since we were born.”
When I heard this, sir, I told her that she was lucky to have such a master and to live on Mount Malaya. But Madhavilata replied: “Blessed one, please tell me now who you are, who have endowed this life of ours with fruit.”121
“Beautiful girl,” I said to her, “We are just as you see. We came to Mount Malaya because we were eager to enjoy a ride on the swing.”
At this, her mouth and eyes immediately opened wide. “The swing is right here!” she told us. “Please enjoy it for as long as you like.”
ताव महाणुमईए सहसा भणिआ
आ N] या ed
ऒ
ऒ N] उ ed
 णिअ
अ N] य ed
-वअं
अं N] यं ed
सीओ । अंदोल
दोल ed] होलं N

 ॥ ३८७

 । परिआ

ज्ज

इ छ

ण-वम्महो व्व बा
बा ed] वा PJBN
लाहिँ

] N
ह तुम्हे वि ॥ ३९१
Mahanumati wasted no time in telling her friends: “Go ahead and play, and we’ll take turns!” Then all of the girls suddenly wanted nothing more than to be the first to have a ride. They gathered around the swing and pushed it back and forth, as if it were the God of Love at the spring festival.122
One girl seemed as if she were impatient to make love for the first time: she climbed up on the swing like a woman madly in love climbs up on her lover. The way that she enjoyed it—completely lost in ecstatic bliss—made the others want to enjoy it all the more.123
Thus they took turns on the swing. “We’ve been playing for a long time now,” they said. “Now you should play for as long as you want!”

Then I also took my turn on the swing, brother. I played to my heart’s content, and then I sat down again in the courtyard with the jewelled mosaic floor. We rested for a bit, and started on our way back, when at that very moment the Siddha prince appeared from that direction. The Yaksha girls all took notice. “It’s him!” they said, as they eagerly fixed their gaze on him. The girls stared at him as if they had fallen in love even before seeing him—but he came straight to me and Madhavilata. Then, brother, I bowed to him from a distance and said: “May all your wishes be granted, and may you and your relatives live long!”

“Blessed lady,” he said, “may what you have wished for us really happen. As a matter of fact, everything that could go right for me today has already. My lady, this land is difficult to reach for even the master of the thirty gods.*
master of the thirty gods: Indra.
 But today your feet have blessed it, and transferred their color—red like a lotus of offering—to its surface.124”

 ॥ ४१०
As he was saying these words, his eyes turned off to the side, and at that instant he saw Mahanumati’s face—her eyes darting nervously with desire. He made a pretense of moving his eyes back and forth so that, through the corner of one eye, he could eagerly catch a glimpse of Mahanumati again and again. And when he saw Mahanumati return his glances, her gaze gracefully and delicately meeting his own, her loveliness reached its peak. She was beautiful, but this flash of playful grace made her even more beautiful, like a flowering bud on a tendril-laced vine. At that very moment her eyes suddenly filled up with tears of joy, like water-lilies in the morning dew. As her extremely delicate gaze opened up—her eyelashes spreading apart and her pupils rolling around restlessly between them—it looked as if the desire within her heart was putting forth the shoots of pleasure. With each heaving, nervous breath, her breasts came up, as if to support her lotus-face, which was cast down in modesty. She was just breathing—but these breaths, heavy and irregular, made her saree slip down and reveal her breasts, as if she intended to show him. Her whole body seemed enveloped in waves of sensation that made her hair stand on end, as if it were expanding to contain him as he entered into her from head to foot.125 The beads of sweat that were trickling over the curving folds of her midsection made it look as though her breasts were pots that were overflowing with the water of loveliness. The God of Love directed her gaze at him—but it grew weary and fell askance, unable to break through the shield of decorum formed by her friends who stood around her. And for just a second, that young man’s eyes fell off to the side and met hers, guarding with their quickness his heart’s disquiet.

His hair stood on end all over his body, as if love itself—watered by the moonlight of her moon-like face—were putting forth its shoots. Both of their eyes were gasping, yearning to behold each other in full, but choked by their resolve to keep their feelings hidden. Both of their hearts skipped, filled with the sensual and delicate play of love at first glance, but anxious about its fulfillment.

ए परिणमि

ओ वासरो विसज्जे
ज्जे ed] जे N
ह । दिअ
अ] व N, य ed
सस्स को वि
वि ed] व N
 कालो कुमार
र ed] रि N
 णे संमरेज्जा
ज्जा ed] जा N
सु81 ॥ ४२०
But I saw all this, and I said to Mahanumati, “Sister,126 the day is turning into night. What is keeping us from going back, my dear?” Once I said this, the would-be lovers realized that all of us around them had something quite different on their minds.
Then I addressed him: “Prince,” I said, “our time here has run out. The pleasure of seeing you is like nectar. Who is lucky enough to have its full measure? The ones who get to see you before their eyes, day and night, are truly blessed. And we too, just in coming here today, have found our lives’ purpose. So please, from now on, let us take great care that we visit each other so that our love can grow. Right now, however, the sun is setting and the sky is starting to crawl with snakes, the very sight of which is poisonous, which will make the journey back impossible for us. That is why there is fear in my heart. The evening is coming. Please bid us farewell while there is still some time left in the day, prince, and take care to remember us.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च तेण भअवइ
भअवइ] भयवइ ed, णरवर N

 विसं प

णासइ दंसण-व
व Ned] प B
ह-संठिओ एसो ॥ ४२६
“My reverence,” he said, “speaking with you freely is a privilege of a very few in this world of living beings who have stored up reserves of merit. But enough of these formalities. What you have said to me has pleased me so much. You should have no fear of poisonous snakes right now. Once, in fact, not even the gods could come here to Mount Malaya because its stands of sandal trees were all filled with enormous serpents. My father felt that the Siddha people could not enjoy its snake-infested sandal groves, and so he worshipped Garuda. He gave my father this ring, called Nagari.*
Nagari: “enemy of serpents.”
 Take it. Those serpents in the sky will have no power over you.” Let alone those in the sky—the poison of even the serpents in the underworld will come to nothing, once this crosses their sight.”
भणि
] N
अं
अं] यं ed
 च मए

हुअं

अं N] यं ed
 ॥ ४३०
“Please, prince,” I said. “If you transfer it from your hand to the hand of this princess, it will surely ward against every kind of poison.” On hearing this, although he was anxious to conceal his feelings out of modesty, the drops of sweat forming on his face gave away the delight he felt in his heart.
Then, eager for the pleasure of touching her hand, he offered himself to her, holding her right hand in his left hand, and he took so long to put the ring onto her ring-finger that Mahanumati and I flashed a secret smile at each other.

 इमीऎ तहिं ॥ ४३३
Then, at the touch of his hands, she virtually liquefied, like a statue made of moonstone at the touch of the moon’s rays.127 Her figure was already beautified by the presence, in a single moment, of every conceivable kind of grace, but the love welling up within her finally turned it into ambrosia. She was quivering with panic, and so she threw her arms around Madhavilata’s neck, prince, and spoke to her:
किं भणिमो सहि सव्वोव

-दंसण-समूसुओ कीस गरुएसि ॥ ४३६
“What can I even say? My heart is far beyond all formality with you. But just once I must ask you to listen to me carefully.”128
Then there was nothing that Mahanumati did not tell her at length, in all seriousness and with the closest affection.
“Mistress,” said Madhavilata, “don’t talk that way. My heart is ever eager simply to set eyes on your lotus-feet. Why are you making me out to be so great?”

 अम्हे

 वि
वि NB] हि ed, हिं P
 पत्ताओ
ओ Ned] उ B
 ॥ ४४३
As Madhavilata spoke these words, Mahanumati clung even more tightly around her neck, and the Siddha prince felt that he was the one she was embracing.
What happened next, brother, was that Madhavilata gave Mahanumati a necklace of large pearls in appreciation for her invitation to Alaka. In this way Mahanumati took her leave of Madhavilata and started back toward her vehicle with all of her friends. But even as her friends hurried her along, her gaze did not move with her from its spot: it kept waiting for her heart, which was not coming back. “Don’t go” the bees seemed to say, mistaking her feet for fragrant lotus flowers and swarming around them, momentarily halting her exit.
As soon as our vehicle arrived, I too said a long farewell to Madhavilata and to the prince, and then quickly boarded the vehicle. My eyes ran off in that direction to keep watch over my heart, and with my head turned back, I somehow made it all the way back to Alaka.129


Kuvalayavali’s Story: The sunset (444–465)

लं व रवि-बिंबं ॥ ४४७
दंसण-जोग्गं
ग्गं ed] गं N
 पि रहंग-मिहुण-दुव्विसह-दंसणं जाअं
अं] आ N, यं ed
 । बिंबं
बिंबं ed] तिव N
 विअ
अ N] य ed
ड-णहा
णहा ed] द्धो N
सोअ
अ N] य ed
-कुसु
सु ed] N
म-गुंछा
गुंछा ed] गोत्था N, गुत्था B
रुणं रविणो ॥ ४४८
In the meantime, like a garment slipping down, the sun’s rays began to disappear, exhausted by their long journey across the wide expanse of the sky, and it passed dimly over the peaks of the mighty mountain in the west.130 The sun left its course in the sky and disappeared from the sight of man: even the mighty lose their position and fall into obscurity.131 The mountain bore the setting sun on its crest: for the sun in the west is like a brave warrior, beloved by all, being carried in his final moments.132 Whatever was left of the sun’s rays was stretched faint and thin across the sky, so that the mountain seemed to be wearing the round flower of a golden lotus bestrewn with red filaments. The sun came to resemble a cluster of bright-red Ashoka blossoms in the wide expanse of the sky. Nothing could be more beautiful—but the pairs of Chakravaka birds could not bring themselves to look upon it.133
णवरि
णवरि JBNed] निवडि P
 अ
अ N] य JBPed
 कमेण जलणिहि-वेला
वेला ed] N
-जल

-विलुलिओ
ओ Ped] ओ P, य J, उं B

सरइ

 । त

-रुआ

णुमेअं
अं] यं ed, अ N
 जाअं
अं N] यं ed
 वणराइ-तरुगहणं
वणराइ-तरुगहणं N] रण्णं व वण-गहणं Jed, रत्तं व गयणयलं P, रन्नं व भुवणयलं B
90 ॥ ४६१
Finally the sun slinked away, shimmering in the waters of the ocean’s shore, like Rudra was being worshipped on the beach with a handful of rose flowers. The twilight glimmered intensely in the sky, as if the setting sun had broken open the ocean and opened up a hoard of shining jewels. It was as if the fruit of the sky, the sun, had ripened over the course of the day, and its juice—the twilight—came forth when it fell against the western mountain. As the twilight spread over it, interspersed here and there with blackness, the sky became dark red, like ichor coming through the temples of a black elephant, or wine flushing the cheeks of a dark-skinned woman. The darkness mixed with the cow-dust in the dusky horizons, which seemed to contract, pulled down by the heavy orb of the setting sun. The darkness took over the sky, as if the black bar of a scale had risen up, its other end weighed down by a heavy mass of gold in the form of the sun.134 The face of the night, where a faint darkness blended with the remnants of the twilight, took on the complexion of a deep blue saffron flower that has just dried out.135 It seemed as if the enmassed darkness was a swarm of bees flying towards the great lotus that was the day, worn as an ear-ornament by the sun, as it closed. The sky looked like a sandalwood tree, and the darkness was the black serpent that encircled it when the sun, that bower of luminous herbs nearby, had shed its leaves.136 The sky is like a pond, and when the lotuses that are the shining sun begin to close up, the water-lilies that are the constellations begin to open, and the water below that is the darkness can hardly be seen. The entire sky was covered by the darkness, as if it were smoke making its way up from the submarine fire, once the waters of the ocean had been split open by the falling of the sun.137 As if it were produced by a heavy storm clouds, as if it were fashioned by swarms of bees, the darkness, black as a cuckoo’s neck, spread all over. The sky seemed to be made of darkness, the horizon seemed to be painted with lamp-black, and dense growth of trees in the forests could only be made out from the sounds of the owls.138
अह दीसिउं

] N
-दिट्ठि-भिण्ण
भिण्ण N] भिन्न PJB
 व्व पुव्व-दिसा ॥ ४६५
Then the white lustre of the lord of the night*
lord of the night: the moon.
, still hidden behind the mountains, began to appear, like the white flag flying ahead of his chariot.139 A small trickle of light from the crescent moon appeared at the very edge of the darkness, as if Vishnu had displaced a bit of milk from the milk-ocean as he slept.140 As darkness was streaked by the effulgent scattered rays of the moon that stretched towards it, it came to look like the Vindhya mountains with waterfalls cascading down its peaks.141 Then the eastern sky was perforated by the red beams of the moon, still hidden behind the mountains, as if it were pierced by the angry glares of the women who steal away at night.142


Kuvalayavali’s Story: Kuvalayavali confronts Mahanumati (466–509)

संग-परम्मु

ही जाआ
आ N] या ed
 ॥ ४८०
Meanwhile Mahanumati here, grievously wounded by love’s arrows, took leave of all her friends and entered her bedroom. At that moment I too went and touched the feet of her mother, Vasantashri, my heart pounding because of how long it took us to come back.
“What’s wrong, child?” she said. “Have you forgotten where you live? You could at least tell me where you were playing, and why it took you so long to come back here.”
“Mother,” I said, “we were playing on the swing made from jasmine tendrils, hung from the top of a sandalwood tree, on Mount Malaya. Mahanumati has not come to touch your feet here only because her body is so tired from playing on the swing for such a long time.”
On hearing this, her mother had me go right in, but I didn’t see Mahanumati in her bedroom. Oh, how I worried! Where could she be, her body burning from love’s arrows, without me? Well, what else could I find out? The bed was so disheveled from a helpless body tossing and turning on it, and the ground was littered with flowers, that she must have gone from the bed to the ground, from the ground back to the bed, and from the bed to the roof to be cooled by the moon’s rays. With that in mind, I climbed up to the jeweled pavilion with a faint heart and racing thoughts.
That was just about the time when the darkness, shattered by the rays from the moon standing atop the eastern mountain, began to retreat into the openings of caves. The goose of the moon, spreading the wings of its light, came from the treetop of the eastern mountain into the pond of the sky, with all of its pure white constellations for water-lilies,143 and with its spreading rays like long lotus-stalks, the moon drunk up the darkness like streams of water in that great pond, the region between heaven and earth. The moon’s rays were burning her in her separation from her beloved: so did the lotuses in the pond tell me, with all of their face-like flowers closed into buds. The lotus flower turns away from the moon, as if she knows that she cannot bear to love someone whom she could only see from time to time.
