 । सीसंतं लहुई-हो
ई-हो ed] ओहोहो N
इ होइ गरुअं
अं N] यं ed
 असीसंतं ॥ ४९३
When I saw the moon, the whetstone for love’s arrows, I thought to myself that it could be deadly for those who were suffering separation.144 Then I immediately saw her there, her body tormented by the arrows of the irresistible god of love, laying on a terrace inlaid with crystal and jewels. I went up to her side, put my hands on her helpless body, and said to her: “Why are you suffering like this, dear friend? Why did you leave your bedroom, friend, and come up to lay on this crystal terrace inlaid with jewels? Are you so busy taking in the breeze, cooled by all of the flowers of the garden, that you have forgotten to even breathe? Did you hear the loud buzzing of the bees, wild to drink the nectar of all of the flowers, and then collapse at once as if you had just been stung? Why is it, my friend, that your limbs are motionless and sweating, even in the cool night, when they are glanced by the rays of the moon? Why are you making your bed disheveled by constantly rolling around, your body gripped with delirium and choking back your anxious sighs? Doe-eyed girl, why are you imagining that the servant girls nearby are talking to you, and then making these broken-off replies? I can’t understand what you are saying, much less what it means! And why are your eyes constantly staring off into nothing, with tears welling up from a heart transfixed by all manners of worry and care? Why have you limply cast your delicate arms above your head, letting them fall and smear the painting on your face, and making it resemble the orb of the newly-risen moon?? Doe-eyed girl, why is the sandal paste drying out as soon as you put it on your chest, which is red with the pollen from the filaments of fresh lotuses?145 The grievous pain of one’s heart becomes becomes light when told and heavy when not: so why do you continue to conceal it from me?”
तो तं इमीऍ आअ

 ॥ ४९६
When she heard this, she turned her eyes down in embarrassment, and said: “I won’t concealing anything, least of all something so bad. Young women adorn their families with their modesty, and yet my cursed heart has begun to feel something that is hardly in keeping with this. How could I tell you? How could I not tell you, unspeakable as it is? No, I must tell you what I have kept secret for so long. Please listen.

 अविणअ
अ N] य ed

मो NJBed] मा P
इण्णा ॥ ५०१
“When they saw that Siddha prince, friend, these dishonorable eyes of mine took me on the road to immodesty. What can I say? Yes, even though I know, my friend, that it is so completely opposed to a prince’s nature, that damned God of Love has put my under the yoke of shameless women. Friend, since, with a smile and apparently without reason, he gave me such a gift as this, the boon of Garuda that counteracts the poison of all serpents, I remembered his enormous courtesy towards me, and as my attachment to him grew, I imagined that he was fond of me too,146 and soon, constantly thinking about the way he acted, his noble birth, his character, his learning and modesty, and his unparalleled good qualities, I was well on the road to immodesty.

ण अंगाण
अंगाण N] अंगोण B, अम्हाण ed
102 ॥ ५०५
That is why I climbed up here, where it is cool from the moonlight and the breeze, without telling even you, feeling as though shame has wrecked my very existence. And so I was tortured all the more, friend, when the rays of the moon turned out to be harsh as sharp saw-blades: I cannot bear to look at them! The rays of the moon now seem to have set the horizon ablaze, and the breeze from the garden now blows poison. So tell me where I can go, as wicked as I am and tortured by the blazing fires of love, that this pain will finally not destroy me?”
भाणिअं
अं N] यं ed

अ N] य ed
-सहि सव्वं

डिज्जंतं
तं Ned] ते B
 ण तहा गुप्पंतं जह फुडीहोइ ॥ ५०७
Then I said: “Dear friend, other people have said all this. There is just no way to keep the madness of love a secret. Anything else can be concealed. But this secret of love is different: it is never so plainly visible when it is revealed as when it kept secret.”147
एवं भणिऊण मए भाउ

णं ॥ ५०८
तेण वि से संताओ जा ण गओ भट्ट
भट्ट Ned] तेणु B
उत्त उवसामं । अवलोइअं सुभीआए
अं सुभीआए N] यं सुभीयाए ed, ऊण भीयाइ B
 तो मए दक्खिणाहुत्तं105 ॥ ५०९
After saying this, brother, I made her a bed of fresh lily-pads, cool with camphor, sandal, and lotus-stalks. But even that pained her, and as long as it did, sir, I gazed frightfully towards the south.


Kuvalayavali’s Story: Madhavilata Arrives (510–523)

ता झ

त्ति ण

अ N] य ed

अ N] य ed
ण-कमलाऍ अ

प्पिओ दइअ

दूईए ॥ ५१३
अह सो इ

मीऍ पि
पि ed] सहसा पि N
अअ

म-कर-कमल-पसंग-लद्ध-माहप्पो । सहस त्ति स
स ed] सा N
हरिसाए पओ
ओ JNed] उ P
हरोवरि परिट्ठविओ ॥ ५१४
अ
अ ed] त N
ह सो मए वि
मए वि ed] वि मए N
 सहसा परिओसु
ओसु Jed] उसु P, उ N
प्फुल्ल-लोअ
अ N] य ed
ण-मुहीए । अणिसामिअ
अ N] य ed
-वअ
अ N] य ed
णप्पाहणाऎ
ऎ NJed] इ P
 सो वाइओ लेहो ॥ ५१५
But just as I was looking in that direction, sir, there suddenly arrived Madhavilata, her lotus-face faded from her long journey through the sky. I was elated, and before anything else I rushed to embrace her, and then she embraced me, brother. She could hardly contain her delight. Then, when Madhavilata saw the blossoms strewn all over the bed by Mahanumati’s arms, she immediately praised the God of Five Arrows.*
God of Five Arrows: the god of love.
 After that, this messenger from her beloved presented us with a crown of flowers from the tree of the gods*
tree of the gods: usually the Pārijāta tree which is said to grow in Indra’s heaven.
 and a letter on a palm leaf, with a look of satisfaction on her lotus-face. She immediately took it and joyfully held it to her breast, considering it invaluable because it had touched her beloved’s lotus-hands. Then she started to read the letter out to me. Her mouth and eyes both flowered in delight, so much that she didn’t even hear the words that she read:
सत्थि
सत्थि ed] अत्थि N
 मलआअ
आअ N] याय ed
ओ
ओ NJed] उ P
 सुंदरि तुह माहवाणिलो लिहइ । लेहं समुच्च
च्च ed] द्ध N
अ
अ N] य ed
 त्थं भावेज्जसु किं खु
किं खु ed] N
 ब
ब ed] व N
हुएण । ५१६
इमि
मि ed] म्मि N
णा वि णव-पओहर-पसंग-सुह-सीअ
अ N] य ed
लेण हारेण । ण समि
मि ed] म्मि N
ज्जइ तुह-दंसण-संव्वग-गओ
ओ JNed] उ P
 अणंगग्गी ॥ ५१७
“Svasti!*
svasti: “prospertity”; a typical epistolary greeting.
 Madhavanila writes this to you, dear, from Mount Malaya. Please take this letter into consideration, brief as it is. To get straight to the point: Even this necklace, which your young breasts have touched and made pleasantly cool, cannot put out the fire of love that has raged since seeing you in person.”
तं सोऊण इमीए णिहुअ
अ N] य ed
-णिब

ए ॥ ५१८
When she heard this, she pressed her hands close together, and with both of lotus-eyes turned down, she did reverence in her heart to the God of Five Arrows.*
: the god of love.

109 ॥ ५२१
Just at that moment Madhavilata delivered to me, too, a message from the prince, as follows: “Madhavanila respectfully reports to you, madam, that you should not be addressed with formalities or cliches, but I must say that no-one is as dear to me as you are, and that will be a wonderful place, that will be a wonderful day, that will be a wonderful sight for the eyes, and that will be a wonderful moment when I see you again as well.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च मए सहि माहवीलए कहसु केण कज्जेण । ब

-मणाए ॥ ५२२
“Madhavilata, my friend,” I said, “tell me, why were you so surprised earlier, when you did reverence to the Bodiless God?”*
Bodiless God: the god of love.
भणिअं

च ed] N

ओ दिअ
अ N] य ed
सं ॥ ५२३
“Blessed lady,” she said, “it is because the prince, too, in that lovely place of his, spent the whole day deep in thought about your virtues.”148


Madhavilata’s Story: The Sunset (524–536)

ता अत्थ-सेल
ल NJed] लं P
-संकेअ
अ] य ed, त N
-संग-सुह-समिअ
अ N] य ed
-दिअ
अ N] य ed
स-संताओ । अणुराअ
अ N] य ed
-णि
णि Ned] नि PJ
ब्भरो वारुणीए अवगू
गू ed] ऊ N
हिओ सूरो ॥ ५२४
Meanwhile the burning pain of the sun in the daytime was relieved by his pleasure on meeting his beloved in the mountain of his setting, and there he, full of affection, was embraced by the Lady of the West.*
Lady of the West: vāruṇī, the western direction personified as a woman.
जाआ
आ N] या ed
 सिहर-समारूढ-विविह-विह
ह ed] हं N

-दलोहा । 111तामस

गलंत-परितलिण

द्ध-तिमिरा तरु

ग्घाआ
आ N] या ed
 ॥ ५२५
The patches of trees were filled with all kinds of birds who crowded among the leaves in the upper branches, and their shadows grew thinner until they blended in with the darkness.149
संझाअव-दव-दड्ढं
अव-दव-दड्ढं] यव-दव-दड्ढं ed, वणअवडद्धं N

णअलं

 ॥ ५२६
In that moment the sky was like a forest burned by the fire of the twilight, with the stars for its smoldering trunks and the horizons blackened by the ash of the darkness.
णिण्णासिअ

 ॥ ५२७
Suddenly the surface of the earth seemed to be swallowed by darkness, which wipes out all of the regions of the sky and snuffs out the light, as if by death, which destroys all hope and blots out the lives of men.150

Meanwhile the moon glimmered, red and half-risen, its shimmering orb the temple of divine elephant half-submerged in the ocean.
सुर-सुंदरि-समअ

The disc of the moon was slightly red, and the light that spread out from it had the pale red color of the cheeks of a divine maiden drunk with wine.

The darkness, broken here and there by the shining rays of the moon, was like a thicket of tamāla trees, broken up by foam that emerged from the sea as it was churned with Mount Mandara.

As the soft rays of moonlight fell in thin and uneven patterns through the darkness, the sky looked like an emerald floor interlaced with gold.

As rays of light from the moon, standing atop the eastern mountain, broke through it, the expanse of the sky looked like a black snake in the middle of sloughing off its skin.

Meanwhile, as the thick darkness was blotted out by the rays of the steadily-whitening moon, the horizons looked like they were washed clean by the waves of the ocean of milk.

The night-lilies began to open, as if they themselves were filled with the darkness the moon had overrun, and swarms of bees crowded around them in pursuit of the fragrance that came from within their still half-closed petals.

The remnants of the darkness that were left after the onslaught of the moon’s rays seemed to take shelter in the caves of their protector, Mount Malaya.

 संगमं ससिणा
णा NPed] णो J
 ॥ ५३६
The day lotus got the worse deal: her lover was not skilled in the arts, famous throughout the world, and a delight to all people, as the moon was full, visible throughout the world, and soothing to all people.151


Madhavilata’s Story: The Prince in Longing (537–560)

ता
ता ed] तो N
 दुल्ल
ल्ल ed] ण्ण N
ह-लंभ-जणाणुराअ
अ N] य ed
-रस-मउइअ
उइअ] उइय ed, ओस N
म्मि ओअ
अ ed] व N
द्धा । हिअअ
अअ N] यय ed
म्मि से कुमारस्स स
स ed] रस्स N
सि-अ
अ N] य ed
रा कुसु
सु ed] शु N
म- बा
बा ed] वा PJN
ण
ण NPed] णु J
 व्व ॥ ५३७
When the prince’s heart was softened by feelings of love for his far-off beloved, the moon’s rays sunk into it like the flower-arrows of the God of Love.
तो सो
सो ed] से N
 विसट्ट-वर-कुसु
सु ed] शु N
म-गंध-विस
विस ed] N
-धारिओ विअ
विअ N] इव ed
 कुमारो । तत्तो च्चिअ
अ N] य ed
 तुम्हालुंखिआ
आ N] या ed
ए भूमीए सु
सु ed] मु N
णि
णि N] वि ed
सण्णो114 ॥ ५३८
The fragrance of the night lotuses that had just opened up was like poison to the prince, and so he collapsed on the ground that you had touched.
दूसह
ह ed] हं N
-संताव-परव्वसो
सो ed] सा N
 वि तब्भू
तब्भू ed] तभ्भू P, तंभू J, तभू N
भि-फं
फं ed] फुं N
स-सु
सु ed] N
ह-लुद्धो । सव्वंगिअं
अं] यं ed, अ N
 णिसण्णो णेच्छइ णलि
लि ed] ण्णि N
णी-दलत्थु
त्थु ed] त्थ N
रणं ॥ ५३९
Although in the grip of overpowering pain, he longed to touch that ground. Without even spreading a bed of lotus petals, he laid his whole body down on it.
115णि
णि ed] ण N
ज्जइ णिसाए चंदो
चंदो ed] N
 णिसा वि चंदेण दोहि मि अणंगो
अणंगो ed] अणंगो मअणंगो N
 । मअ
अ N] य ed
णेण वि से विरहो
विरहो Ped] विरओ J, रहा N
 दूरं
रं ed] रा N
 तेणा
तेणा ed] त्थणे N
वि संतावो
वो ed] ओ N
 ॥ ५४०
The night brought up the moon, and the moon brought along the night. Both brought on his desire, his desire, longing, and his longing finally brought on immense pain.
सो
सो ed] से N
 वम्मह-सर-पस
स ed] हा N
राउ
उ ed] ओ N
रम्मि हिअअ

ढ-सरेण व वम्महेण पासो व्व से खित्तो
व्व से खित्तो Jed] व सो व्व खित्तो N, व्व सोक्खिन्नो P
 ॥ ५४१
His heart was wounded by the arrows of love, and the necklace that he wore on top of it was like the snare that the God of Love threw over him after running out of arrows.
इमिणा
इमिणा ed] णिम्मिणे N

साइं ॥ ५४२
Then it was the cruel moon who, like a demon, that reduced his body to skin and bones in an instant.
तो सो अणिमिसिअ
अ N] य ed
च्छं
च्छं ed] त्थ N

अ N] व ed

For a long time he stared with unblinking eyes into the expanse, and then begged the moon, the breeze, and the garden he was in:
हंहो मिअं
अं N] यं ed

रुज्जाण रक्खह

“Oh moon! Oh breeze! Oh beautiful garden! Please keep my beloved’s body, soft as the filaments of a fresh day lotus, safe in my heart!”
तं तह सोऊण मए भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 सहसा कुमार अलमिमिणा । अ

अअ N] यय ed
मा एत्थ ॥ ५४५
As soon as I heard this I said, “Prince, stop talking like this. It doesn’t suit you. Where is that beloved of yours now?
कीस तुमं

What, have you forgotten yourself, that you are babbling to someone who isn’t there? In time, even the most impossible love will find fulfillment.

And besides, they say that love has many stages, and one by one they take over the lover’s body.
पढम

Delight is when the glances exchanged between two people cause their hearts to glow with a feeling of attraction. Delight gives rise, in both of them, to affectionate words.
आलाव-वइअराणंतरं

After exchanging affectionate words, a concern arises in their hearts, and this concern ushers in the God of Love, who arrives with his bow strung.
तक्कालुक्कंठा

Now that they are full of longing for each other, they figure out their next steps, and encourage each other by sending and receiving words through messengers.152
दूइ-समागम-संतुट्ठ-हिअअ

In their hearts, delighted by the messenger’s arrival, they imagine the all of the good qualities of their lover, and then they think about them day after day without end with their friends.153
गुण-कित्तणाणु
णु ed] ण N
राओसुआण
ओसुआण] ओसुयाण ed, उस्सुआ N

सो ed] N

Constantly thinking about a lover’s good qualities removes all doubt, and when the two of them finally meet—what can I possibly compare it to?

What is savored when two lovers come first come together in love is the seventh rasa, something special and unique, that produces total bliss.154

The special kind of pleasure that a lover gives during a first encounter is not described in our traditional texts, and even lies outside the scope of the great poets.155
तह संभोअ
अ N] य ed

After the pleasure of union, they begin to become comfortable with each other, From comfort arises fondness, and from fondness grows attachment.

When affection reaches its peak, however, some device of fate will introduce a separation, and that is the stage of love that is most difficult to endure.

I can tell just from looking at you that you’re in just such a stage right now. You have lost control of your body to the searing pain of love’s consuming fire.”

“You certainly have a lot of words for me,” he said. “Keep talking. What you haven’t done is go within the range of the glances cast from the corners of her eyes, glassy, still, and cast aside.

If you can tell me something, anything, that she tells you, then go. But right now, don’t go on talking about these things.”

That is what he told me, my reverence, when he sent me here. Now, having seen your four lotus-feet, I will be on my way.


Kuvalayavali’s Story: A Message for Madhavanila (561–587)

भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च मए सुंदरि एवं णिअ
अ N] य ed
-सामिणो
णो ed] अं N
 भणिज्जा
णिज्जा ed] णेजा N
सु । मज्झ वअ
अ N] य ed
णेण ब
ब ed] व N
हुसो जह सो णण्णं
णण्णं ed] णंण्ण N
 विअप्पेइ
अप्पेइ] यप्पेइ ed, अंपेसि N
 ॥ ५६१
“Beautiful girl,” I said, “please tell the following to your lord in full, and make sure that he knows I said it, so that it does not raise his suspicion:
भण्णसि णीसेस-पसिद्ध-सिद्ध
द्ध ed] ध N
-सिर-मउड-घडिअ
अ] आ N, य ed
-चलणस्स । मलआ
आ N] या ed
णिलस्स
स्स ed] स N
 तणओ
ओ ed] उ N
 सज्जणणि-समुब्भवो
मुब्भवो ed] भमो N
 तं सि ॥ ५६२
You are said to be the son of Malayanila, whose feet are adorned by the crowns on the heads of all of the famous Siddhas, and born from a respectable mother.
एसा वि महाणुमई जम्मि कुले जाणसि च्चिअ
णसि च्चिअ] णिसि व्विय P, णसि च्चिय J, णं चिअ N
 तुमं पि । कं
कं ed] क N
 सेसं जं सीसइ वअ
अ N] य ed
-विहवाआ
आ N] या ed
र-सीलाण ॥ ५६३
You already know quite well the family that our Mahanumati has been born into. What remains to be said of the glory of her youth, her conduct, and her character?
ता एसो अण्णोण्णाणुसरिस-विण्णाणराअ
विण्णाणराअ] विण्णाणुराय ed, चित्ताणुआअ N
-संवाओ
संवाओ N] सवाओ J, सब्भावो P
119 । पुण्णमइआण
इआण N] इयाण ed, मईयाण PJ
 काण वि जाअ
अ] य ed, N
इ इह जीअ
अ N] य Jed, व P
-लोअ
अ N] य J, ग P
म्मि ॥ ५६४
Hence this is a perfect match of intelligence and affection, the privilege of a very few in this world of living beings who have stored up reserves of merit.
ता
ता JNed] तो P
 णिअ
अ N] य ed
-ताअं
अं N] यं ed
 पडिबो
बो ed] वो N
हिऊण एअं
अं] N, यं ed
 कुमारिआ
आ N] या ed
-रअ
अ N] य ed
णं । सव्वाअ
अ N] य ed
रं वरिज्जउ उह
उह ed] N
आ
आ N] या ed
ण वि उहअ
अ] य ed, N
-लोअ
अ NJ] य Ped
-सु
सु JNed] मु P
हं ॥ ५६५
Therefore tell your father and marry this gem of a young woman with all due ceremony, a source of pleasure in both worlds for both of you.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च
च ed] N
 तओ
ओ ed] ए N
 मा
मा ed] म N
हविलआ
आ N] या ed
ए अंबम्ह
अंबम्ह ed] अंवंम्ह P, अम्बम्ह J, अंवम्ह N
 तुम्हि
म्हि ed] म्ह N
 जं
जं ed] ज N
 भणह120 । एत्ताहे देवी देउ किं पि संदेसअं
अं N] यं ed
 पइणो ॥ ५६६
Then Madhavilata said: “As you say, madam. Now do you, my lady, have any message to give to your future husband?”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च महाणुभईए ईसि-लज्जा-परात्तिअ
अ N] य ed
-मुहीए । अइ-उज्जुआ
आ] या ed, क्खा N
सि पिअ
अ N] य ed
-सहि किमहं जाणामि संदिसिउं ॥ ५६७
“My dear friend,” said Mahanumati, turning her face down slightly in embarrassment, “you are too forward. What message could I possibly send?
सोक्खाइँ
इँ ed] इ N
 तुमाहिंतो
हिंतो ed] हिन्तो N
 तत्तो णिद्दा तुमाहि मे जीअं
अं N] यं ed
 । पिअ
अ N] य ed
-संगमं तइंतो
इंतो ed] इतो N
 जं जाणसि तं कुणि
णि ed] णे N
ज्जासु ॥ ५६०
On you depends my happiness, my ability to sleep, my life. On you depends my union with my beloved. You know what you need to do.”
अह एवं गहिअ
अ N] य ed
त्था अम्ह-सआ
आ N] या ed
साओ सा गआ
आ N] या ed
 दूई । अम्हे वि अ
वि अ] वि य ed, हि मि N
 तिस्सा गुण-गणाणुगहणे
णुगहणे ed] णुगहणेणुगहणाण N
 पअ
अ N] य ed
त्ताओ ॥ ५६९
Then, bearing our words in mind, our messenger went from our presence, and we started to appreciate all of her good qualities.
तो ववगआ
आ N] या ed
ए
ए N] इ ed
 तीए ब
ब ed] व N
हु-वि
वि ed] वि N
ह-चिंता
चिंता ed] चिन्ता N
-विअ
अ N] य ed
प्प-संधमि
धमि Ped] दुम्मि N, ढुमि J
ओ । सविसेसं पज्जलिओ इमीए
इमीए Ped] इमिइ J, एमीए N
 हिअए अणंगसिही
हिअए अणंगसिही] हियए अणंग-सिही ed, अणंगसिही हियए P, हियए अणं J, हिअए अणंगग्गी N
 ॥ ५७०
When she had gone, the fire of love burned all the more in her heart, fanned by all kinds of worries and doubts.
तत्तो
तत्तो Ped] ता तं N, तो तं J
 मुहु
हु ed] ह N
त्त-मेत्तं
त्तं ed] तं N
 णिरुद्ध-णीसास-णिच्चलच्छी
च्चलच्छी ed] व्वच्छली N
ए121 । णिव्वा
व्वा ed] व्व N
हिऊण भाउअ
अ N] य N
 इ
इ ed] ए N
मीए संपइ समुल्लविअं
अं N] यं ed
 ॥ ४७१
Then, brother, for just a moment, she managed to hold back her sighs and hold still her eyes just long enough to stay:
सहि सिट्ठं जं
जं ed] च ज N
 माहविलआ
आ N] या ed
ए जं चम्ह
चम्ह Ned] चंम्ह PJ
 तेण

किंचि ed] किं चि P, संचि J, इंचि N
 अप्पाहिअं
अं N] यं ed

वअणं] वयणं ed, त्तस्स N
 ॥ ५७२
“Friend, you have sent in return nothing that compares with what Madhavilata said and the message that he sent to me.
मा मह हआ
आ N] या ed
ए दोसेण दूस
स ed] से N
हं माणसं वहंतस्स । अण्णं पि किंपि

 होही स
स ed] N
विसेसं जं इमाओ वि
जं इमाओ वि ed] जइमाउत्ति N
 ॥ ५७३
What a wretch I am! He is suffering this anguish because of me! I hope that nothing else even worse than this will happen to him!
तेणाहं पज्जाउ

I am absolutely heart-sick over it. Come, let’s go to Mount Malaya! I will give myself to him in person!

The fire of love is burning my heart, and I cannot bear to waste any time. You heard it yourself. His life, too, hangs in the balance.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed

 साहेसि ॥ ५७६
“Dear friend,” I said, “I have heard, seen, and experienced myself the awful things that the cursed god of the Flower Arrows can do. What can you possibly tell me?
पे
पे ed] प N
रिज्जंतो पुव्वक्क
क्क Ped] क JN
एहिँ कम्मेहिँ
हिँ ed] हिं N
 केहि
केहि ed] N

मि JN] वि Ped
 वराओ । सुहमि
मि ed] म N
च्छंतो दुल्लइ-जणाणुराए जणो पडइ ॥ ५७७
It is because he is led on by some deeds done in the past that a miserable wretch who only wants to be happy will fall in love with someone he can never have.156
दुल्लह-समागमुद्दू
मुद्दू Ped] मे दू JN
मिआ
आ N] या ed
ण कामीण
ण ed] अण N
 जं समावडइ । दुक्खेण ते
ते ed] ता N
ण प
प ed] प N
र-वसण-पेच्छिरो ड
ड ed] उ N
ज्झउ अणंगो123 ॥ ५७८
For once let the Bodiless God*
Bodiless God: the God of Love.
 himself burn with the pain that befalls tormented by the impossibility of fulfillment, since he loves to watch it happen to other people.
जेहिँ
हिँ ed] हिं N
 दइ
इ ed] इं N
अं
अं N] यं ed
 ण णा
णा ed] अ N
अं
अं N] यं ed

अ N] य ed
-दुक्खा सुहीण ते पढमा । जाणं चिअ
चिअ] च N, चिय ed
 पिअ
अ] अअ N, य ed
-विरहो जाणसु
जाणसु ed] सवाण N
 दुक्खी
क्खी ed] क्खा N
ण ते पढमा124 ॥ ५७९
The happiest of all, those who have not truly known pain, are those who have never known love. And the unhappiest of all, you know, are those who are separated from their loved ones.
दुक्ख-घडिराण खण-विहडिराण विरहावसाण-विसमाण । दुप्प
प्प ed] प N
रिअ
अ N] य ed
ल्ला
ल्ला ed] त्ता N
ण रसं धण्णा ण मुणंति पेम्मा
म्मा ed] मा N
ण ॥ ५८०
Painful to create, destroyed in a second, terrible when it reaches the stage of separation and always difficult to preserve—lucky are those who have never known the taste of love.
तह वि हु मा तम्म तुमं
तुमं ed] उअ N
 मा झू
झू ed] रू P, तुझू J, स N

प्पा N] त्ता Jed, न्ना P
णं
णं PJed] ण N
 । को देइ हरइ को वा
हरइ को वा ed] को वा हरइ N
 सुहासुहं जस्स जं विहिअं
अं N] यं ed
125 ॥ ५८१
But still, you must not give in to this anguish. Don’t surrender yourself to it. A person’s pain and pleasure are ordained: who can give it, and who can take it away?
जह संब

 एरिसं कज्जं126 ॥ ५८२
Something like this should be done in such a way that your good qualities will attach to it, that people all around will be pleased with it, and that your parents will give it their approval.

They should be done with careful planning, so that as bland as they seem in the beginning in the end they have the savor of pure nectar, and they will never come in for ridicule.157

That’s why I have to tell you, dear friend, that a girl who does whatever she feels like, like me, will earn an especially bad reputation in the world.

You are the daughter of Nalakubara, born from Vasantashri. How, then, could you do something that goes against your birth? People will say things, dear friend.158

Offering yourself in marriage? That’s what miserable creatures with no prospects do. That’s not the way of girls born into great families.

Let me tell you about what I personally had to go through. We have a moment, dear friend, so please listen with an attentive heart.”


Kuvalayavali’s Story: Kuvalayavali’s Story (588–641)

आसि पसाहिअ
अ N] य ed
-चउ-जलहि-व
व ed] च N

अ N] य ed
-रसणा-वसुंधरा-णाहो

ण्णासिआरि-वक्खो

आ] या ed, N
 विउलासओ
ओ ed] णो N
 णाम
णाम JNed] जाओ P
129 ॥ ५८८
Once there was a king, the lord of that maiden, the earth, who wears the four oceans as a girdle, the destroyer of his opponents, named Vipulashaya.
आ-साअ
अ] N, य ed
रेक्क-छ
छ ed] च्छ N
त्तंक-वसुमई
ई ed] इ N

आ-दिवंगणा-लच्छी Ned] [lacuna of ten syllables] P
 । आ-भुअ
अ] व N, य ed
ण-जअ
जअ N] जिय P, जय J
-सिरी
री ed] ची N
 जस्स खग्ग-मग्गे
खग्ग-मग्गे Jed] सुवणुखगे N, खग्गमग्गं P
 चि
चि ed] वि N
रं वसिआ
आ N] या ed
130 ॥ ५८९
Vasumati, the earth, who stretched as far as the ocean under his royal parasol alone, Lakshmi, wealth, who reached as far as the women of heaven, and Jayashri, victory, who filled the limits of the world—long did they stay on the path of his sword.159
सो तीए असंतुट्ठो णर-णाहो
णर-णाहो ed] रणमोहो N
 एक्क-भुवण-लच्छीए । दाऊण णिअअ
अअ N] यय ed
-
] र ed, रं N
ज्जं णीसेसं दिअ
अ N] य ed
-वराण ग
ग ed] रा N
ओ ॥ ५९०
But that king was not satisfied with the royal splendor of merely one world. He made over the entire state to his ministers and then left.
सुर-सरि-जल-सिसिर-तुसार-सित्त-तरु
तरु JNed] बहु P
-कुसु
सु ed] शु N
म-वासिअ
अ N] य ed
-दिअं
अं N] यं ed
ते । तुहिणाअ
अ N] य ed
लस्स कडए महातवं चरिउमाढत्तो
चरिउमाढत्तो JNed] महिय [lacuna] P, चरिउमाढत्तो J
131 ॥ ५९१
He started to practice severe austerities on the slope of a snowy mountain, where flowers perfumed the air and ice from the waters of the celestial Ganges clung to the trees.
तत्था
त्था ed] च्छा N
संखं कालं

-सरीरो । मअ

-विह

ग-उल-सहावो व

-सअ
अ N] य ed
णो ॥ ५९२ ॥
For an inconceivable time there he sustained his body with roots and fruits, living as the beasts and birds, wearing the bark-cloth and sleeping on bare stone.
पत्त-हर-कअ
अ N] य ed
-णिवासो णीसंगो जा तहिं
हिं ed] हि N
 तवं
तवं ed] व N
 चरइ । ता भीएणाणत्ता सुरवइणा सुर-वहू रंभा ॥ ५९३
While he lived there without attachments in his house of leaves and practiced his austerities, Indra was apprehensive, and sent forth the divine maiden Rambha.
[रंभे वण-गहण-परिट्ठिअ
अ] य ed
स्स वेत्तासणस्स वर-मुणिणो । गंतूण कुणसु विग्धं उग्ग-तवासत्त-हिअअ
अअ] यय ed
स्स ॥ ५९४]132
“Rambha, there is a great sage deep in the forest seated on a stool of cane, his heart set on fierce austerities: go and interrupt him.”
[सुरवइ-लद्धाएसा वर-वअणा
वर-वअणा] वयरयणा J
 झत्ति स-हरिसावयवा । संपत्ता वण-गहणे कअ
अ] य ed
-णिअ
अ] य ed
मो वर-मुणी जत्थ ॥ ५९५]
Upon receiving this command from Indra, her body thrilled with delight, and she immediately came to the forest grove where the sage practiced his vows.
[ता सुर-वहु-दंसण-चालिअ
अ] य ed
म्मि मुणिवर-मणाम्मि मअ
अ] य ed
णग्गी । पज्जलिओ तव-तरु-डहण-लालसो मोह-घअ
अ] य ed
-सित्तो ॥ ५९६]
Then, on seeing the divine maiden, the great sage’s heart was shaken and the fire of lust blazed within in, quick to burn up the trees of his austerity and sprinkled with the ghee of delusion.
सा किअचि
किअचि] कियचि Jed, किञ्चि P, केव्वि N
रं पि कालं तेण समं मअण

-मणेण । अच्छंती उ

-सुरेसा
सा ed] सो N
133 ॥ ५९७
She stayed with him for a good while, lust clouding his mind, and became pregnant, much to Indra’s delight.
तिस्सा
स्सा ed] सा N
हं तिहुअ

ढा ed] ढं N
 ॥ ५९८
I was born from the womb of that Rambha, the most beautiful woman in the three worlds. After my birth, she left me and returned to heaven.
अह ताएण वि
ताएण वि Jed] वाएणेवि P, अह ताएण वि J

अ] य ed
रेण तहिं ॥134 ५९९
Then, dear friend, my father humbly beseeched the forest gods of that place, concerned that I was separated from my mother.
तो ताहिँ
ताहिँ ed] तहिं N

 ॥ ६००
They nourished me with the nectar of fruit juices, and soon enough I was walking on my feet and in good health in that penance grove.
वक्कल-कुप्पासा

-सुहं पत्ता135 ॥ ६०१
With my body covered in a garment of bark, I lived the life of a young animal:160 I enjoyed playing with the fawns.
दिअ
अ N] य ed
हेहिँ

बु ed] वु N
द्धी ॥ ६०२
As the days wore on, childhood left me behind, and my thoughts turned to serving at my father’s feet.
आणे

I would bring all the different kinds of bulbs, roots, and fruits that the trees produced, and I was happy with the occasional tasks of sweeping and polishing up.

Just as night was turning into day, I just had to gather flowers from the many different types of trees, so I set out for that mountain forest where the trees were in full bloom, the sky echoed with the calls of all kinds of birds,

When I saw him I extended to him a handful of flowers with equal amazement, reverence, and modesty, eager to know what he had in mind.

“Flower-picker, you are wandering in this grove, with bowers and canopies formed by young vines and the charming noise of swarms of buzzing bees, without fear or hesitation like a graceful celestial girl at play. Who are you?”

When I heard those first enthralling words, dear friend, I told him plainly my home, my family, and my name.

“Well then, beautiful girl, there is nothing to stop us from looking upon each other, is there? I too was born into a spotless family of Gandharvas.

My name is Chitrangada. I came down because I was eager to have a look at you. If you would oblige me, then the God of Love will have done the right thing.

Such were the words he spoke to me, laying the charm on thick, and soon enough my heart too seemed to fill the whole space from heaven above to hell below.

Friend, I was hardly aware of it, but the tears of joy that filled my eyes seemed to tell him that my heart was already won over.

An intense panic seized me and my mouth fell open, and through the sharp breath that escaped, what I felt inside gave itself to him.

Is there anything, dear friend, that my sweat, my hair standing on end, did not betray to him? I was weak in the knees, as my hopeless trembling made perfectly clear.

द्धी ॥ ६३०149
In this way my virtuous and ever-modest mind was dragged down by my treacherous and love-conned body.
तो वाम-पअं
अं N] यं ed
गुट्ठे
ट्ठे ed] हे N
ण तत्थ धरणी-अ
अ] य Ned
लं लिहंतीए । भणिअं
अं] यं ed, अं च N
 अणुच्च
च्च ed] व्व N
-सद्दं
द्दं ed] व्वं N
 अहोमुहच्छं
मुहच्छं ed] तहत्थं N
 च सहि तस्स ॥ ६३१
Thus it was that I drew a line on the ground
with the toe of my left foot, friend,
and spoke to him softly
with my eyes cast down:
को एअं ण
अं ण] यं ण ed, अणं N
 पसंसइ कस्स व इमि
मि ed] मी N
णा ण होइ परिओसो । को तुम्ह ण संबज्झ
बज्झ ed] कज्ज N
इ कह व
कह व Ped] कं व J, वाम N
 ण दी
दी ed] ई ed
सइ तुमाहिंतो ॥ ६३२150
“Who wouldn’t give their approval to this?
Who wouldn’t be pleased with it?
Who wouldn’t want you as a relation?
Doesn’t it seem that way to you?161
इअ
अ] य ed
 जइ मं महसि महाणुभाव वण-तावसिं पि णाऊण । ता गंतूणं म्ह तवोवणम्मि ताअं
अं] यं ed
 चिअ
चिअ] विय P, चिय Jed
 भणेसु ॥ ६३३151
So if you still desire me, noble sir,
despite knowing that I am a forest-dwelling ascetic,
then please go and tell my father
who lives in the hermitage.”
तो
तो ed] N
 तेण पुणो भणिअं

] णो ed, णे N
 ॥ ६३४
At that point he said, “Enough of this!
How long are you going to take?
The love in my heart cannot bear to wait
after having had the pleasure of seeing you!
कालंतर-परिवसिए अवसर-चु
र-चु ed] च्चु N
क्कम्मि मअ
अ N] य ed
-सिलिं

च्छि । विग्घ-सहस्साइँ

अ N] य ed
इच्छिए कज्जे ॥ ६३५152
Doe-eyed girl, if time slips by
or if the moment is missed,
thousands of obstacles will fall in the way
of the heart getting what it wants.”
एवं भणिऊण वअं
अं N] यं ed

सारिओ हत्थो ॥ ६३६
As he spoke these words, friend,
the hair on his arms stood on end,
and once my hand slipped to the side,
he grabbed it, knowing my heart’s desire.162
तो तेण मज्झ

 ॥ ६३७153
Then he quickly consummated his marriage to me,
dear friend, and I, cheated by accursed love,
just as quickly forgot all of my family’s principles.
तह तत्तो चिअ
अ] य ed
 पिअ
अ] य ed

रुग्गीए । कलअं

ठि-कलअ

After that, when the whole area around us
buzzed with bees crazed for the nectar of flowers,
echoing with the indistinct sound of cuckoos,
णि

blocking the rays of the sun
with a thick growth of vines and shoots,
perfuming the stands of trees
with the fragrance of all kinds of flowers,
सत्तच्छअ
अ N] य ed
-सुह-पाअ
अ N] य ed
व-तलम्मि इच्छाए अच्छि

व ed] अ N
सावसाण-समए संभरिओ सहि मए अप्पा ॥ ६४०
I stayed with him for a long time
under the pleasing shade of the saptacchada tree,
and then, friend, when the day was almost over,
I remembered myself.
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च
च ed] व N

लो होइ एत्ताहे ॥ ६४१156
“Beloved,” I said,
“this was indeed inappropriate,
and it will not turn out well for us
if fate is not favorable to us right now.”
अइ-गरुओ अवराहो विसमो ताओ
ओ ed] वो N
 असंकिरो मअ
अ N] य ed
णो । अविम
विम ed] मि N
रसिअं
अं N] यं ed

आ N] या ed
णिमो कह विपरिणमइ
कह विपरिणमइ ed] कत्थ परिणामो N
 ॥ ६४२157
The offense is very serious. My father has a temper.
We didn’t second-guess our feelings,
and we didn’t think through our actions.
I don’t know what will happen next.”
ता तेणाहं भणिआ
आ N] या ed
 मा
मा ed] सा N
 भाअसु

-वसइं । वच्च

म्ह वि
वि ed] N
गअ
अ N] य ed
-रोसो
रोसो Ped] रोसा J, सिणिणहेवो N
 होही कालेण तुह ताओ ॥ ६४३158
Then he said to me, “Don’t be afraid.
Right now you can come to my place.
Let’s go. In the meantime,
your father’s anger will fade.
दिण्णाण अदिण्णाण
दिण्णाण ed] N
 अ
अ] य P, इ J, N
 आहव-गहिआ
आ N] या ed
ण सइँ
इँ ed] इं PJ
वराणं च । परिणीआ
आ] या ed
ण कुमारीण णत्थि अण्णं भणेअ
अ] य ed
व्वं ॥ ६४४159
When women are led off in marriage
after battle or after a svayaṃvara,
it doesn’t matter whether their parents
have given them or not.
They have no say in the matter.”163
अह एरिसे स
स Jed] ससस P
मुल्लाव-वइअ
अ] य ed
रे सुअ

ओ तत्तो च्चि
च्चि ed] वि N
अ
अ] य ed
 आगओ ताओ ॥ ६४५
Right after exchanging these words,
lovely girl, my father arrived on the scene,
exhausted from looking all over for me.
ता तेण समं पिअ
अ N] य ed
-सहि सहसा गंधव्वराअ
अ N] य ed
-तणएण
ण ed] N
 । एक्क-विमाणासीणा
सीणा ed] N
 सच्च
च्च N] व्व N
विआ
आ N] या ed
 णवर ताएण ॥ ६४६
That very moment, dear friend,
my father saw me sitting in the same vehicle
as him, the son of the Gandharva king.
[And the great sage said:
“You wicked man! Go off to the world of demons!
Overcome with lust, you stole away
my daughter with utter rashness!”]
[वुत्तं च तओ तेण वि गंधव्वेणावि कयव
गंधव्वेणावि कयव] गंधव्वेण वि कयाव॰ conj. AU
राहेण । भयवं इमस्स होही कइया आउस्स पज्जंतो ॥ ६४८]
[And then that Gandharva,
caught it the act, said:
“Lord, when will that life
that you have cursed me to end?”]
[भणियं च महामुणिणा पावसु रे पाव रक्खसालोयं । दुहिया मे अवहरिया कामासत्तेण अइ-रहसा ॥ ६४७]?
[भणियं च तओ इसिणा णियत्त
णियत्त] नियत्त P
-रोसेण पुत्ति-णेहाओ
णेहाओ] ॰नेहाओ P
 । अइ-दुसह-सुहड-पारद्ध-संगरे जाव सि--ह-आ
सि--ह-आ] सिरसि हओ conj. AU
 ॥ ६४९]
[Then the sage’s anger subsided
and out of love for his daughter he said,
“When you are struck on the head
in a battle fought by inconquerable warriors.”]
[ता सोय-मज्जिअ
मज्जिअ] मज्झि अ (P would separate मज्झि and अ॰ P
-विसद्द-गयण-पसरेण पेच्छमाणाए । साव-पवणेण हरिऊण-----त्थ वि पएस्स
हरिऊण-----त्थ वि पएस्स] हरिओ णवरि पिओ कत्थ वि पएसे (the conjectural letters of the copyist are म्मा चि क for the four blank places.) conj. AU
 ॥ ६५०]
[Then I watched as the winds of the curse
silently came down from the sky,
filling me with grief,
and just took my beloved
off to some other place.]
तो मे झस त्ति पडियं अविणय-गिरि-गरुय-तुंग-सिहराहि । हिययं लज्जा-भय-कुलिस-ताडियं पिव णिरालंबं ॥ ६५१
All of a sudden my helpless heart,
as if were struck with the axe of shame and fear,
fell down from the highest peak
of the great mountain of my immodesty.
अह अयस-महा-सीहेण तासिया पलइऊण वेएण । एक्कं णिउंज-कणई-वियाण-गहणं समल्लीणा ॥ ६५२
Then I quickly ran off in fear of the
great lion of notoriety,
and reached a thicket covered over
with a thick growth of vines.
ता तत्थ मं णिलुक्कं
मं णिलुक्कं] मं निलुक्कं P, मिणंलुक्कं J
 अविणीयं पेच्छउ त्ति मा ताओ । इय कलिऊण व
व] य P, व J
 सूरो णीओ लज्जाऎ अत्थमणं
अत्थमणं] अत्थवणं P, अत्थमणं J
 ॥ ६५३
Soon after, as if to prevent my father
from finding me, his immodest daughter,
hiding there, the sun disappeared in humiliation.
मह दुक्ख-दुक्खियाहिँ व दिसाहिँ अंधारियाइँ वयणाइं । मह भय-भीयाइँ व संकुयंति
संकुयंति] संचरंति P, संकुयंति J
 वणयर-समूहाइं ॥ ६५४
As if pained by my pain, the faces
of the directions became dark.
As if frightened by my fear, the creatures
of the forest all withdrew.
ता रवि-रह-वडण
वडण] विहण P, पडण J
-विसट्ट-जलहि-मग्गुग्गएण व तमेण । पायालाहिँ व समयं विलुंपिओ
पायालाहिँ व समयं विलुंपिओ] ॰हिं व P, ॰हिम्व J
 णहयलाहोओ
होओ] ॰भोओ P, ॰होओ J
 ॥ ६५५
Then the darkness, as if coming up
from a breach in the ocean opened up
by the descent of the sun’s chariot,
emerged from the netherworld
to plunder the curving plane of the sky.164
ता हं कणइ-विया
कणइ-विया] कणयविमा॰ P, कणइविया॰ J
णाऑ सणिय-सणियं महा-भउप्पेत्था
महा-भउप्पेत्था] ॰प्पेच्छा P, ॰प्पेत्था J
 । अण्णण्ण-तरु-वणंतर-णिलुक्कमाणी समल्लीणा ॥ ६५६
In the meantime, still in the grip of terror,
I slowly came out of the thicket of vines
and moved from one clearing to the next.
ता ण
ता ण] ता न P, ता जा ण J
 पिओ ण विमाणं ण य ताओ णेय किं पि तं चिण्हं । जं पेच्छिऊण जीयं मुहुत्तमेत्तं विमालेमि
विमालेमि] पि मालेमि conj. AU, P would read विमालेमि as one word.
 ॥ ६५७
Finally, when I saw that there was no sign at all
of my lover, or his vehicle, or my father,
I was able to keep myself alive
for just a moment more.
अह तं दट्ठूण मए सज्ज मसाणं व झत्ति दुप्पेच्छं
दुप्पेच्छं] दुपेच्छं P, दुप्पेच्छं J
 । चिर-मोह-लद्ध-सण्णाऍ मुक्कयंठं चिरं रुण्णं ॥ ६५८
Then it suddenly became as awful to look upon
as a cremation ground.
Who knows how long I fainted for,
or how long I sobbed uncontrollably
when I regained consciousness.
हा ताय गय-सिणेहो कीस तुमं तक्खणेण मह
मह] महं P, मह J
 जाओ । अविणीए वि अवच्चे हवंति कलुणासया
कलुणासया] ॰सया P, महा J
 मुणिणो ॥ ६५९
“Father! How could you just lose
all of your love for me in an instant?
Even if a child is far out of line
aren’t sages supposed to be compassionate?
हा अज्जउत्त तुह णेह-बंधणोबद्ध-जीविया विहिणा
विहिणा] विधिणा P, विहिणा J
 । वोच्छिण्णा विस-वल्लि व्व वियड-कप्पद्दुमाहिंतो ॥ ६६०
Beloved! When my life was tied to yours
by the bond of love, fate cut me loose
like a choking vine cut
from an enormous wish-granting tree.
हा अंब तए वि अहं हय-णामा जम्म-वासरे मुक्का । इण्हिं असरण-हियया कं जं सरणं पविज्जिस्स
पविज्जिस्स] पवज्जिस्सं conj. AU
 ॥ ६६१
Mother! I must be cursed, since you too
left me on the day I was born.
Now, with nowhere left for my heart
to turn to, who will I turn to?
हा भयवईऒ वण-देवयाऒ दंसेह पिययमं मज्झ । तुम्हं सरण-पवण्णा विऑय
विऑय] P would separate वि and ओय., वि उय अणाहा conj. AU
-अणाहा विवज्जामि ॥ ६६२
Blessed gods of the forest! Let me see
my beloved. I am turning to you for help.
Separation has turned me into a widow.”
इय एवं बहुसो विलविऊण परिचिंतियम्हि हियएण । किं मह हयाऎ इमिणा अप्पडियारेण रुण्णेण ॥ ६६३
I wailed like this over and over,
and then I thought in my heart:
“What is the use of this damn crying?
It won’t do anything to help!
दुक्खावगमो
वगमो] ॰वसमो॰ P, ॰वगमो॰ J
वाओ णण्णो मरणाउ दीसइ कहिं पि । ता इह सत्तच्छय-पायवम्मि पासं णिबंधिस्सं ॥ ६६४
The only way of removing this pain
seems to be death.
So I will tie a noose
onto this very saptacchada tree.”
एवं हियए परिभाविऊण वलियम्हि वक्कल-वरिल्लं
वरिल्लं] वरिल्लं P, विरल्लं J
 । सच्चविया जम-हर-वत्तणि
वत्तणि] वोत्तणि P, वत्तणि J
 व्व हियइच्छिया साहा ॥ ६६५
With these thoughts in mind,
I tied up my bark clothing
and fastened my gaze onto a branch
which my heart now longed for,
the route to the house of Yama.*
Yama: the god of death.
भणियं च णिबद्धंजलि-पणाम-पुव्वं मणम्मि झाऊण । भयवं विस्स-पयावइ जइ किं पि मए कयं सुकयं ॥ ६६६
Putting my hands together in reverence,
I said to myself, “Blessed creator of all,
if ever I have done a good deed,
ता अण्णम्मि वि जम्मे सो च्चिय मह पिययमो हविज्जासु
हविज्जासु] हविज्जाउ conj. AU
 । मा होज्ज पुणो एवं-विहाण दुक्खाण संभूई ॥ ६६७
then may the same person be my beloved
in another birth. But please,
may it not be the cause of so much sorrow!”
एवं भणिऊण मए उवबद्धो जा तहिं दुमे अप्पा । तो अद्धुड्डीणे
अद्धुड्डीणे]
जीवियम्मि गयणे सुओ सद्दो ॥ ६६८
As I was saying this,
and tying myself to the tree,
half of my life had already left me
when I heard a sound in the sky.
अइ अलमलमिमिणा
मिमिणा] ॰मिविणा P, ॰मिमिणा J
 तुज्झ पुत्ति ववसाय-साहस-रसेण
रसेण] रसेण P, सरेण J
 । वीसत्था होह
होह] होहि conj. AU
 खणं अहं खु जणणी य तुह
तुह] तुहं P, तुह J
 पत्ता ॥ ६६९
“Oh, stop! We have had enough, my girl,
with your taste for rash decisions
and dramatic stunts.
Take heart for a minute.
It is me, your mother.”
[ता झत्ति णह
णह] नह
-यलाओ अवयरिऊणम्ह सहि सुजणणीए । तं तोडिऊण पासं गहियाहं सुयणु उच्छंगे ॥ ६७०]?
[Then suddenly, dear friend, my mother
came down from the sky, cut the noose,
and clasped me to her chest.]
जाणामि तेण मुणिणा णिरावराहा वि मुक्क-संगेण । परिसेसिया
परिसेसिया] परिपेसिया conj. AU
 सि बाले दूरं णिक्करुण-हियएण ॥ ६७१
“I know how you must be suffering, my girl,
since that sage has abandoned you
for no fault of your own.
Compassion is far from his heart.
ता तुज्झ सो अगम्मो सुर-लोओ जत्थ सइ णिवासो म्ह । अत्थि मह हियय-दइओ जक्खो णलकूबरो णाम ॥ ६७२
At the same time, you cannot come to
the place where I live, the realm of the gods.
But I have a close friend,
a Yaksha named Nalakubara.
वित्ताहिवस्स तणओ सुयणो सच्च-व्वओ
सच्च-व्वओ] सच्चव्वओ P, सच्चवओ J
 पियाहासी
हासी] ॰भासी P, ॰हासी J
 । पडिवण्ण-वच्छलो सइ
सइ] सइ P, सइं J
 परोवयारेक्क-पत्तट्ठो ॥ ६७३
He is the son of the Lord of Wealth,*
Lord of Wealth: Kubera.
a good man, devoted to truth, kind in word
and devoted to his promises,
with an uncommon skill for helping others.
तस्स समप्पेमि सुहेण जेण पिय-विरह-दुक्खमइया
मइया] ॰मइया PJ
 वि । सुवयंसिया हिँ समयं वच्चंति अलक्खिया दियहा ॥ ६७४
I will commit you to his care,
and the days will happily pass by unnoticed
in the company of friends, despite the torment
of separation from your beloved.”
एवं भणिऊण चिरं अंबाऎ सिणेह-संगय-मणाए । एत्था
एत्था] तत्था॰ P, एत्था॰ J
णिऊण पिय-सहि समप्पिया तुज्झ तायस्स ॥ ६७५
My mother said these words,
her heart filled with affection,
and then brought me here
and gave me to the care of your father.
तो तद्दियसाहिंतो तुम्हं अंबाऎ तह य ताएण । तुम्हाहिँ वि सविसेसं सच्चविया एचिरं
विया एचिरं] P would read ॰वियाए चिरं.
 जाव ॥ ६७६
Starting from that day, up until now,
your mother and father, and you yourself,
have taken extraordinary care of me.
तेणत्तियं
तेणत्तियं] P suggests the saṁdhi तेण+एत्तियं., तेणेत्तियं conj. AU
 पि कालं तुह णेह-णिबद्ध-जीवियासाए । सब्भाव-समप्पिय-माणसाऍ दुक्खं चिय ण णायं ॥ ६७७
This whole time, you see, your love
strengthened my will to live,
and with my heart entrusted to your kindness,
I felt no sorrow at all.
तुह सुह-सुहिया तुह दुक्ख-दुक्खिया तुज्झ हियय-गय-हियया । तेण णिवारेमि इमं गुरु-जण-मण-बाहिरं कज्जं ॥ ६७८
Happy with your happiness,
and pained at your pain,
my heart following yours,
that is why I must stop you from doing something
beyond the approval of your parents.
[इय
इय] ईय P
 गुरु-जण-मण-रहियं कज्जं जो कुणइ सुयणु सच्छंदो । सो दुक्ख-हरं जायइ
जायइ] जाअइ P
 जह जाया हं खु सच्छंदा ॥ ६७९]?
[Lovely girl, whoever goes their own way
and does something without the approval of their parents
will become a house of pain,
sure as I have become, going my own way.]
जइ णिच्छ
णिच्छ] ॰णिच्छ P, णिच्छि॰ J
एण एयं तुह हियए संठियं कुरंगच्छि । ता अंबाए सीसइ स च्चिय सव्वं समाणिहइ ॥ ६८०
If this decision is settled in your heart,
doe-eyed girl, then tell your mother,
who will set everything in order.
अहवा सयं पबोहेमि तत्थ गंतूण तं चिय कुमारं । जेण वरॆज्ज
वरॆज्ज] विरि॰ P, वरे॰ J
सि दिज्जसि एक्केक्कम-कुल-हरीसेहिं ॥ ६८१
Otherwise I myself will go
and tell the prince, so that you
may be requested and given in marriage
by the heads of each household.
इय एव
एव] एस P, एव J
-विहो धम्मो दिट्ठो
दिट्ठो] दिट्ठो P, देट्ठो J
 देवेहिँ दिय-महेसीहिं । अविरुज्झंतो
अविरुज्झंतो] अविर॰ P, अविरु॰ J
 पिय-सहि उहयाण
उहयाण] उहयणा P, उहयाण J
 वि उहय
उहय] P, ओहय J
-लोग-सुहो ॥ ६८२
This is the dharma that the gods,
brahmans, and great sages have taught.
When you abide by it, dear friend,
it leads to happiness in both worlds.


The expedition to the underworld (1008–1101)

इअ
अ N] य ed
 सो ति
ति ed] वि N
लोअ
अ N] य ed
-सुंदरि-समागमा

सा-विओ
ओ ed] तु N

वि Ned] अ B
समत्थो । णाअ
अ N] य ed
ज्जुण-गुरुणा
णा ed] णे N
 जाणिऊण पुहईसरो भणिओ ॥ १००८
Thus his hopes of reuniting with the most beautiful woman in the three worlds were dashed, and the lord of the earth*
lord of the earth: King Satavahana.
 was utterly distraught. His guru Nagarjuna found out and said to him:165
हंहो सिरि-सालाहण कीस तुमं
मं ed] अं N
 एरिसं समुल्लव

 । णण्णं
णण्णं ed] णाणं N, एवं B
 कुमईण फलं संसारे संसरंता
रंता ed] रन्ता N
ण ॥ १०११
“Listen, Your Majesty. Why are you talking like this? Are you a common man that your words should be so ignoble? People in this world who don’t live for the pursuit of righteousness, pleasure, or liberation—they spring up and die off like grass.166 They’re born just to die, and die just to be born again. For the small-minded, that is all there is to worldly existence.
सुमई

ण

इँ

इँ
इँ ed] इं N
 जर-वाहि-रहि
रहि] om. N
आ
आ N] या edB
इं
इं Ned] ण B
 ॥ १०१५
“But the wise, my lord, can obtain incomparable powers here in this world, without having to give up their own lives. Don’t you understand what death means? Once you go, you’re gone. Think about it. How you would ever see your loved ones again? Why should you die a useless death like a common man? If you don’t want your kingdom here, fine. Then let’s go to Patala. The enjoyments that this realm offers to wise men eclipse those of heaven eightfold; there, a thousand years pass unnoticed, without old age or disease.”167
एवं सुणि
सुणि ed] सो BN
ऊण
ण Ned] णं B
 णराहिवेण उब्बिंब
ब्बिंब ed] विम्व N
-बा
बा ed] वा N
ल-हरिणच्छि । परिचिंतिऊण सुइरं पडिवण्णं
ण्णं ed] णं N
 भिक्खुणो वअ
अ N] य ed
णं ॥ १०१६
My love, with darting fawn-like eyes, on hearing this the king considered the monk’s proposal for a long while, and finally agreed.
अह अण्ण
ण्ण ed] ण N

-पुरस्सरेण णइ

-तीर-संठि
ठि ed] धि N, स्थि B
ओ
ओ Ned] तो B
 राआ
आ N] या ed
 । विजआ
आ N] या ed
णंदेण समं विवराहुत्तं परिक्कंतो
क्कंतो ed] क्कन्तो N
 ॥ १०२१
The next morning, the king transferred his kingdom to his son and set out, impatient to win back Lilavati. His heart was given over to despair, and he was still considering death, but Nagarjuna persuaded him to leave the city. His arrival at the banks of the Godavari river brought unbearable grief to his officers, advisers, servants, relatives, friends and subjects. The king set out with two hundred personal servants, two hundred princes, and a hundred poets. The monk Nagarjuna led them to the bank of a river. The king stopped here, then climbed up towards a cave with Vijayananda.
अह सो पसअ
अ N] य ed
च्छि सुवल्लहेहिँ

ऊण सव्वे वि

 संपइट्ठा महासीहं ॥ १०२३
Then, my long-eyed love, the king and his brave companions reached the mouth of the cave. A lion guarded the opening. The beast opened its terrifying jaws wide and let out a hideous roar. But the brave men walked straight past it and into the cave.

रं ॥ १०३१160
इअ
अ N] य ed
 एरिसं कुरंगच्छि देवदेवस्स मंदिरुज्जाणं । जं पॆच्छिऊण पावंति
वंति ed] वन्ति N
 णरवरॆं
रॆं N] रिं ed
दा
दा ed] दाण N
 महा-सिद्धिं ॥ १०३२
Then, after a few miles, they caught sight of another gate.168 This one was blocked with a large stone slab, and the hosts of Heramba169 stood guard. They said spells before it, and by the end of the night it flew open. A few miles from that place, they saw a temple to Shiva. Atimukta and aśoka trees, tall sāl, piyāl and palm trees offered their shade; bullet wood and cardamom suffused the bowers with their fragrance; jasmine, amaranth, kubjaka, kañcana, and karavīra flowers mixed with patches of puṃnāga, nāgakesara, ketakī, kaṃkellī, and kurabaka; mango and campaka grew amid dense sandal groves and stands of pine; the scent of coral trees and young mālatī blended with fresh jasmine; the smells of white sinduvāra, pink priyaṅgu, and acacia flowers coursed through it; the ground was scattered with offerings of white lotus petals; the bowers resonanted with the buzz of bees drunk on spring’s abundance; the whole sky echoed with the drone of cuckoos; a wealth of jackfruit, peepal and gular figs enhanced the stunning beauty of so many citrons, coconuts, bananas, and grapes: my doe-eyed love, such were the grounds of the temple of Shiva. At the mere sight of it, the heroes acquired the powers they sought.
तो तं भवाणि-दइअं
अं N] यं ed
 भव-भूअ
अ N] य ed
-भआ

अं N] यं ed

हेण णित्थामो

 ॥ १०३५
Then they praised the husband of Bhavānī,*
husband of Bhavani: Shiva.
 who removes the fear of all the world’s beings, and they proceeded a little further until they reached a third gate. This one was fastened with a golden bolt, and covered top to bottom with a crawling mass of serpents.
In it, the king saw a man inescapably caught up in the snakes’ noose-like grip. He said:
भणिअं
अं] यं ed
 च अहो पॆच्छह पाआ
आ] या ed
ल-पवेस-कंखिरो एसो । संजमिओ दुट्ठ-भुअं
अं] यं ed
गमेहिँ अच्छइ महा-पुरिसो ॥ १०३६161
“Look! This great man must have been trying to enter Patala when these wicked serpents imprisoned him.”
एवं भणिरस्स णराहिवस्स ते सुअ

 ॥ १०४०
As the king was speaking these words, lovely girl, those deadly snakes slithered off in all directions, releasing the young man. Then he began to speak:
“O lord of men, thank you! Not a soul has come to these parts—certainly no-one who could free me from that torture, no-one so wise and beneficient, no-one so selflessly devoted to others. What’s left to say? Now that I’m freed from my plight, everything that I have and will have belongs to you.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed
 च राइ
च राइ ed] इमि N
णा सुकअ
अ N] य ed
-क

म्म

मा ed] om. N

किं edB] के P, को N, not specified J
 अत्थ तुम्हे वि
वि ed] हिं N
 ॥ १०४१
“Doer of good deeds,” said the king, “did something not work out for you? What did you come here for? Please tell me.”
भणिअं
अं N] यं ed

आ] या ed
णिलो णाम वसइ सिद्धाहिवो सुविक्खाओ । तस्स सुओ हं पहु माहवाणिलो णाम जीअ
अ] य ed
-समो ॥ १०४५
“King,” he said, “take a seat and I will tell you all the details. I feel like I need to tell someone else. There is a huge mountain whose enchanting slopes echo with the calls of many kinds of birds, where the fragrance of lavalī, cloves and cardamom groves fills the air, where the red rocks of its vales are painted with lac from the feet of celestial women. Its name is Malaya, and it is the realm of the Siddhas. There lives the far-famed king of the Siddhas, named Malayanila. Lord, I am his son Madhavanila, dearer to him than life.”
अह तं सोऊण णराहिवेण उब्बिंब-बाल-हरिणच्छि । अप्पाणं तिहुअ
अ] य ed
ण-सिरि-पसंग-सुहिअं
अं] यं ed, यव्व B
 व
व Jed] च P
 परितुलिअं
अं] यं ed
 ॥ १०४६
Now on hearing this, my love with darting fawn-like eyes, the king considered himself as good as reunited with the most beautiful woman in the three worlds.
भणिअं
अं] यं ed
 च इमो
मो PJNed] मा B

तो ed] त्तो N
 ॥ १०४७
“Brave man,” he said, “here is your signet ring, at the mere sight of which you were instantly freed from that serpentine prison.”
तो तं

Then, as soon as he saw his ring, the Siddha prince’s heart was thrown into spells of exhileration and despair. He could barely get out the words:
“Lord of the earth, where did you get this wonderful ring? Please tell me. I’m astonished. Where did you find it?”
सिट्ठं
ट्ठं ed] द्धं N
 च तस्स पुहई
ई ed] इ N, वी B
सरेण कुवलअ

-दलच्छि णीसेसं । सव्वं पि

इअरं] इयरं ed, वज्जरिअं N
 साअ
साअ] साय ed, आय B, आइ N
रं तेण ॥ १०५०
My lily-eyed love, the lord of the earth carefully told him every last detail about what had happened to Mahanumati.

स्सामो

162 ॥ १०५४
At that point, his heart could not contain its joy, and his eyes opened wide. “After all that,” he said, “why are you still wasting your time here? To think that those hateful snakes kept me tied up here for so long, and it actually turned out for the best! And best of all is that the charm that they took from me and tossed away has fallen into your hands. Please go forth from here. I will come from Malaya mountain to meet you: my parents must be beside themselves with worry, so I will meet them first.”
एवं भणिऊण मि
मि] म Ned
अ
अ N] य ed
च्छि राइणो मलअ
अ N] य ed
-महिहराहुत्तं । परमाणंद-प
प ed] om. N
हिट्ठो सिद्ध-कुमारो गओ सहसा ॥ १०५५
With these words to the king, my doe-eyed girl, the Siddha prince immediately left for Malaya mountain, extremely delighted.
अह तं
अह तं ed] om. N

ताहिँ भणिअं
अं N] यं ed

अं N] यं ed

अ N] य ed

 वर-भवणं । वि

सह विसूरइ सा अम्ह सामिणी तुम्ह दोसेण ॥ १०५७
Then, my slender love, the gate’s golden bolt flew open, and two women stepped out in front of the king.
“Lord of men,” they said, “this is the splendid palace of Ratnaprabha. Please come in: our mistress can’t bear to be without you any longer.”
तं तह
तं तह BN] एवं ed
 सोऊण णराहिवेण णाअज्जुण
अज्जुण] यज्जुण ed, जण N

विअं
अं N] यं ed
 ॥ १०५८
The king heard these words, and put his careful response to them into Nagarjuna’s mouth:
एवं एअं
अं N] यं ed
 जं भणह तुम्हि रअ
अ N] य ed

एसो म्ह

त्तो माहवाणिलो जा ण

सत्थो । ताव म्हं पि ण जुज्जइ एम

-विहं अच्छि
च्छि ed] त्थि N
उं एत्थ ॥ १०६०
“As difficult as it was to get to this palace—Ratnaprabha’s palace, as you say—there is one thing we need to tell you. Until all is right with our good friend Madhavanila, we can’t possibly stay here like this.”
एवं भणिऊण विसज्जिआ

With these words, the king sent the two messengers back, did his reverence to Bhava,170 and left with Nagarjuna.

He reached his city and was thronged by all of his adoring subjects. After bathing in the waters of the Godavari, he entered his palace. The princes’ houses all erupted into celebration, for their earnest desire to see their king again was fulfilled.

Encompassed by all of the supports of kingship,171 the lord wasted no time in giving his general the order to advance at dawn. Immediately a clamor arose from the camp, steadily increasing in volume, filling the sky with echoes as evening’s darkness spread.

“Pack up your tents! Tie up your gunny-sacks! Take along your bedding! Clean out and prepare the stables for the horses!172 Bring out five hundred good elephants—let some stay behind, and let raging bull-elephants take the lead! The Rashtrakuta forces will take lead, and the Solankis will bring up the rear! Our lord will lead the infantry’s advance in the middle of the column!173 Whoever has horses or elephants tied up should drive them at dawn! And get the camels into formation them!”

This noise carried through the sky while the sun, hastened by his love for the woman of the western horizon, sped towards the mountain of its setting. Within the city’s houses burned the flames of so many lamps that it looked like the sun had released its rays to measure out the darkness. Then, like a crest-jewel on the eastern mountain, like a lion raging at the surrounding darkness, like a henna drawing on the cheeks of the woman of the horizon, the moon rose high in the sky.

Then, exhausted from long waking hours, pairs of lovers gave leave to all of their servants, and they all repaired to their own bedchambers.174

She is brooding, and he doesn’t know what to do. But next to her stands her friend, who knows what she’s thinking. Through her raised eyebrow he gains admittance.

Her two eyes open slightly at first, then wide, then they dart back and forth; her cheeks, overtaken by a smile, become full and welcoming: as her anger melts away, the beauty returns to her face.

He’s done nothing wrong, but her unappeasable anger diverts love’s course—for she secretly wants him take her by force.

Love can get worn down by the constant joy of spending time together, in flirting and in lovemaking—like a spear, it needs to be sharpened on the whetstone of anger to become new again.

He’s holding her down, yet she smiles in his forceful embrace; he lowers his head like a menacing elephant, yet she kisses him.

His heart is elsewhere, and her cheeks are shimmering:175 when she takes him in the woman-on-top position, it turns out he was capable of lovemaking after all. She wants to go again, but nothing too ambitious this time: she holds him up, and he stands over her, as they act out a violent scene.

-पम्ह-जुअ

लाइँ हॊंति मिहुणाण ।
] N
अंतो-सुह-परिरक्खण-घडिअ
अ N] य N
-कवाडा
डा ed] ड N
इँ अच्छीणि
अच्छीणि ed] णयणाइ B, च्छीणि N
 ॥ १०८६
The very moment they exchanged words, they incited in each other those feelings that Manmatha presides over,176 and the pleasure of their caresses brought on waves of thrills.177 How beautiful were their lotus-faces, their lips falling open with a single thrilling glance, and their mouths fallings silent with the darting glances of their eyes. They gasped as they marked each other’s bodies with their teeth and nails, and in the enjoyment of close-pressed limbs, moist with sweat, the marks painted on their foreheads slid off. Only these couples would ever know the incomparable pleasures that their encounters gave rise to as they culminated in overflowing rasa. Then, after the violent conclusions to their merciless lovemaking, their whole bodies went slack, their anger vanished, and they slept for the rest of the night. Their eyelids closed in deep sleep, the doors of their eyes slamming shut to protect the pleasure inside.
अह बं
बं ed] वं N

डुरं ed] डर N

अ N] य ed
लाहो
हो JBNed] भो P
अं
अं N] यं JBPed
 ॥ १०८८
णि
णि NJed] नि PB
अ
अ N] य PJed
-णीडुड्डी
णीडुड्डी ed] नीडुड्डी P, णियडी J, नीडुड्डी B, दुद्दी N
ण-विहं
हं NJBed] ह P
ग-णि

वह-कोला

हलाउ

लिल्लाइं । दिण
ण ed] णि N
-सिरि-मुह
मुह ed] सुह B, om. N
-दंसण
दंसण ed] संगम B, वंसण N
-लालसाइँ उट्ठंति
ट्ठंति ed] द्धन्ति N
 व वणा
वणा ed] ठण N
इं ॥ १०८९
पसरिअ
अ N] य ed
-पच्चू
च्चू ed] चू N
स-समीर-विलुलिओ गअ
अ N] य ed
ण-पाअ
अ N] य ed
वाहिंतो
हिंतो ed] हिन्तो N
 । अवसाअ
अ N] य ed
-जल-लवो
जल-लवो ed] सलिलणिव N
हॊ व्व
व्व ed] व N
 गलइ तणु-तारआ
आ N] या ed
-णिवहो
णिवहो Ned] नियरो B
 ॥ १०९०
Then dawn arrived, announced by the morning-songs of the king’s heralds, and with it the joy of his long-awaited expedition. Little by little, the rosy dawn stretched across the eastern sky, and turned it the pale color of a dove’s wing. Amid the commotion of flocks of birds flying up out of their nests, the forests seemed to be rising up to catch a glimpse of the day’s auspicious face.
The multitudes of tiny stars descended, as if snowflakes were fallings from the boughs of the tree that is the sky, shaken by the wind that is the encroaching daylight.
पच्चूस-गअ
अ] य ed
-वरुम्मूलिआ
आ] या ed
ऎ उड्डीण
ण Ped] णे J
-ससि-विहंगाए । धवलाइँ गलंति णिसा-लआ
आ] या ed
ऎ णक्खत्त-कुसुमाइं
माइं Jed] ई P
 ॥ १०९१167
When the elephant that is the dawn pulls out the root that is the night and the bird that is the moon flies off, the white lilies that are the constellations fall away.
पाउं जुण्हा-म
म ed] ग N
इरं जामिणि-विलआ
आ N] या ed
ऎ फलिह-चसऒ व्व
चसऒ व्व ed] रसहोच्चव N
 । मुक्को ण
ण NBed] न P, णे J
हाहि
हि ed] हिं N
 णिवडइ णिलीण-मअ
अ N] य ed
-महु
हु ed] ह N
अ
अ N] य ed
रो चं
चं ed] व N
दो ॥ १०९२
The moon falls from the sky, as if the woman who is the night drank the wine that is the moonlight from a clear glass and lets it fall from her hand— because a bee that is the moon’s spot has landed on it.
संमिल्लंति सुहासाअ
अ N] य ed
-जणिअ

-परिओ

-गहणाइं ॥ १०९३

सास-पवण-पहुऒ
