 व्व । उवभु
वभु ed] म N
त्त-णेह-तणुओ
णुओ NJed] णओ P, णुउ B
 विज्झा
ज्झा ed] ज्ज N
अ
अ N] य ed
इ दीवअ
अ N] य ed
-णिहाओ ॥ १०९४
Beds of night-lotuses now closed up, both as if to savor the satisfaction of the previous night’s pleasure, and in anticipation of the harsh heat of the coming sun.178 Rows of lamps, already weakened from burning all night, fell dark, as if they were blown out by the sighs of women who were finally leaving their lovers’ sides.
चउ-जामालिंगण-सुह-पसुत्त-पच्चुट्ठिआ
आ N] या ed
ण मिहुणा
णा ed] ण N
ण । णिद्दा
द्दा ed] द्धा N
-विरमालस-मंथ
थ ed] त्थ N
राइँ अग्घंति
ग्घंति ed] ग्घन्ति N
 दिट्ठाइं ॥ १०९५
णि
णि NJed] नि PB
द्दा-णिह
णिह NJed] विर P, निह B
सालस
सालस JBed] मासल N, मालस P
-विवलिअं
अं N] यं ed
ग-मासल-वि
वि ed] प N
मुक्क-सासाहिं । सअ
अ N] य ed
णा
णा ed] णे N
इँ कामिणीहिं पिअ
अ N] य ed
 व्व
व्व ed] व N
 सुइरेण मुच्चंति ॥ १०९६
The eyes of the couples looked dreary and tired, for they were just now rising after having fallen soundly asleep in each other’s arms. Langorously rubbing the sleep from their eyes, or tossing their arms and legs, or letting out deep sighs: the womans were as reluctant to leave their beds as they were to leave their lovers.179
का वि कर-कलिअ
अ N] य N
-पस
स ed] सं N
ढिल-कडिल्ल-दर-दाविओरु-लाअ
अ N] य ed
ण्णा । सिचअं
अं N] यं ed
चले धरिज्जइ पिएण सअणं
अणं] यणं ed, मअं N
 विमुंचं
विमुंचं ed] ठिसुच्चं N
ती ॥ १०९७
One woman was leaving her bed: her lover grabbed her by the edge of her skirt, and while she scrambled to hold up it up with her hands, the beauty of her thigh peeked through.
सोहंति कामिणीणं
णं ed] ण N
 णिद्दालस-सो
सो ed] मा N
सिअं
अं N] यं ed
त-णअ
अ N] य ed
णा
णा ed] णे N
ण । उवआर
वआर] अआरु N, वयार ed
-कमल-पक्खलिअ
अ N] य ed
-गमण-मसि
मसि PBed] मस N, मिस J
णा पअ
अ N] य ed
-क्खेवा
वा ed] रा N
 ॥ १०९८
The women’s eyes were dry and heavy with sleep, but their footsteps were soft, shuffling over the lotus petals laid out for them the previous night.
सोहइ जह मलिअ
अ] य ed, ण N
-पसाहणालअं
अं N] यं ed
 कामिणीण गोसम्मि । वअ
अ N] य ed
णं सव्वाअ
अ N] य ed
र-विरइअं
अं N] यं ed
 पि ण तहा
ण तहा] तह नो B, तह अणो N
 णिसारंभे
भे ed] भो N
 ॥ १०९९
How beautiful is a woman’s carefully-prepared hair and makeup at the beginning of the night? But how much more beautiful is it, ruffled and disheveled, at the night’s end?
गोसग्गे गुरु-णिद्दा
द्दा ed] दा N
ललसेण
लसेण PBed] लसएण J, लसाए N
 अद्धच्छि-पे
पे ed] प्पे N
च्छिअ
अ N] य ed
व्वेण । तु
तु ed] उ N
ण्हिक्केण वि वअणेण
वअणेण] वयणेण JBed, वयणेणं P, अणेणि N
 डहइ अज्झा
ज्झा JBed] ज्जा PN
 सवत्ति
सवत्ति Bed] सवन्नि P, सवित्ति J, सवंती N
-अ
अ] य PJBed, om. N
णं
णं PJBed] अ N
 ॥ ११००
छउअंगि
छउअंगि ed] च्छउअंगि N, कीए वि B
 विमुक्काहरण-णीसहं विलुलिआ
आ N] या ed
लअ
अ] य ed, om. N
-विसेसं । हरिआ
आ N] या ed
हर-राअं
अं N] यं ed
 परिसवंति व
व ed] ठ N
अ
अ N] य ed
णं सवत्तीओ ॥ ११०१
In the morning, the new wife can ignite the jealous of her co-wives without saying a word: all she has to do is look at them through her half-closed eyes, heavy from a deep sleep. Her jewelry is gone, her hair and tilaka dishevelled, the rouge has been wiped of her lips—when her co-wives see her like that, my dear, they curse her to stay that way.


Notes to the text

1Not found in any manuscript, but reconstructed from the commentary in B.

2Verse 13 comes after 11 in N, but after the following verse in the other manuscripts.

3Verse 14 is not found in N.

4Verse 15 is not found in N.

5Verse 17 is found only in J.

6विंभल conj. Csaba Dezső, विम्वल ed.

7रंभा P N, रुंभा J, भंभा B ed.

8N skips from the middle of the second line of this verse to the following prose section.

9B writes this verse twice, with पसरंमि for णिअरभ्मि and सारिया वि for सारिआहिं in the second.

10Hemacandra at Deśīnāmamālā 7.19 reads लंपिक्खो.

11Reading अला (N, P as लया) instead of कला (ed.).

12Verse 65, very similar to verse 64, is spurious, only being read in B.

13Read लोअ॰ (K) for unmetrical लोया॰ (ed.).

14Reading पणइआण (JBN) rather than ॰ईण (ed.); the first is read by most mss. and stands for Sanskrit प्रणयिकानाम्.

15This verse is found only in J, no doubt suggested by the previous verse. It is identical to Vajjālagga 635. The word pattalāhattha is obscure (PSM defines pattalī as a kind of tax); Jain and Jain are probably not far off in interpreting it as a decree (ghoṣaṇāpatra).

16Reading असिअमुहीहिं with N, B and P rather than यासियासाहिं with P and the edition.

17Reading वासभवणं with P and B rather than भुयण-वासं with J and the edition.

18B and N present an alternative for the first line: beginning with the prose sentenceअइ चंदलेहे ण णिअसि, B reads the line मलय-समीर-समागम-वस-पसरिय-कुसुम-रेणु-पडिहत्थं. The reading of N is almost identical, with a few errors (समीरण).

19In B and N, the position of 102 and 103 is reversed (the original order must have been as printed here, as the description moves from head to toe).

20Verse 111 is found only in B.

21Verse 112 is found only in B.

22मअण ed, णअर N, B (incorrectly written as वयर).

23पिहु em. Upadhye, पिवि PJB.

24तद्देसआलिएहिं ed; तद्देयसालिएहिं J, तदिअसालिएहि N (likely an inherited error for P’s reading).

25B omits the first line of this verse, and combines the second line with the following half-verse: ताव पइट्ठो सविसाय-हरिसिओ सुयणु परिहारो “at that time, my dear, the chamberlain entered, looking visibly upset”. N omits the second line, and reads a rather corrupt version of B’s additional half-verse (तात पिअट्ठो सविसाऽपहरिसो सुअणु पडिहारो).

26Before verse 142 N reads णीमुहपे से अत्थिणा पुहइह णाहेण.

27Verse 143 is found only in P, which has all dental न in the first line and एरस for एरिस in the second (as well as the regular ya-śruti, which I have kept here).

28Verse 179 is not in N.

29Reading ल्लसिओ (PBN) instead of ल्ललिओ (Jed).

30Reading उव्वूढ, which I conjecture as the source of व्वढ (P), थूढ (J), उच्छूढ (B, whence Upadhye’s च्छूढ), and उवूढ (N).

31Reading पडिअ with P instead of घडिअ.

32उवरुज्झह B, अवरुज्झह ed.

33This verse is also found at Vajjālagga 65, which reads नवरि “only” instead of णेह “love.”

34Missing in B and N.

35Verses 250 to 256 (and the Sanskrit commentary to verse 249) are missing in B.

36जणिअ codd.; मेत्त N.

37Upadhye conjectured कमला उण जऍ for कमलाओ णज्जइ, probably before writing about the use of णज्जइ (a word that expresses a simile) in his endnotes.

38Verse 262 is missing in N.

39भणामि अम्हाण भणिअव्वं JN; विणयोणय-उत्तिमंगाओ ed.

40भणिउं N; भणियं ed.

41तो तं NB; एवं ed.

42सिप्पंत PBN; सिच्चंत ed. (see Turner s.v. siktá.

43Verse 278 is missing in manuscript N.

44Verse 279 is missing in PJN (and thus found only in B). It is probably an interpolation on the basis of the preceding verse.

45Verse 280 is missing in NJ (and read by PB). It is also likely an interpolation (B gives the same number for this and the next verse).

46माहव ed.: मारुअ NB.

47Read करण with B (comm) instead of किरण (ed).

48The mss. give different onomatopoetic sounds in this verse (suṃ in ed., ḍaṃ in N, phuṃ in B).

49B reads पिच्छिऊण गणणाहं instead of भअवअं गणाहिविं.

50उवहसिउं conj. Upadhye; उवहसिअं Ned.

51B reads उव सहि इमाइ पिच्छह विरूवसोहाइ at the beginning of this verse.

52चित्त- (“a worry”) B, ed; वित्त- (“a waste of money”) P, N.

53N adds अह before this verse.

54चिंताभरं समुव्वहइ ed, चिंताभारं उव्वहइ N and (probably) B.

55N copies this verse twice, the first time inattentively and reading the following after सोक्ख-वस-: काणं वरलभो गअवटिअठि [gap] चिंतिअं ताव पि अप्पिअए.

56परिआलिो N and पुरिबालियाओ J; परिवारिओ ed.

57वट्टिअ PBN; वड्ढिअ Jed

58ते Ped; दे B; ए JN.

59हिअअ ed; सहिअ N

60B begins this verse with जत्थ य; N inserts जहिं into the second line.

61दिणहरो॰ N;दिणयरो॰ ed.

62N lacks verse-divisions from 356 to 359.

63After सुहिअ, N skips to the beginning of verse 359.

64B only reads up to णिअंब.

65विसट्टंत ed; परिद्धिअ (= परिट्ठिअ) N

66N lacks this verse.

67सुहा॰ BN, समा॰ ed.

68अब्भुट्ठाणम् PN, सब्भुट्ठाणम् JBed.

69सुसराउ ed; सरसाउ B, सुरसाओ N.

70वत्तणा-वट्ट ed; पट्टियावंध B, वंतिआविद्ध N.

71कमला ed; पउमा B, पउआ N.

72विणिम्मिअं NB; च णिम्मियं Ped.

73॰मेक्क-पंसू-पकीलिया॰ ed; ॰मेक-पसूहिं कीलिआ॰ N, ॰मेक्क-पंसूए कीलिया॰ J, ॰मिक्कमिक्कंमि कीलिया॰ B

74B reads के तुम्हाणे जीवियफलदाणदाढाउ in the second half of verse 384.

75णअण-वअणाऎ BN; वयण-णयणाऎ ed.

76Verse 389 is missing in N.

77समअं BN (the lectio facilior, but syntactically preferable); समुयं ed.

78॰उण्णइ] BN, ॰उण्णय PJ (with orthographic variants).

79वलिआ] ed, किडिआ N.

80After दोण्हि पि in verse 404, N skips to verse 405 (which begins with these words).

81For the second line of verse 420, B reads दूरे अलया नयरी कुमार णे संसरिज्जासु .

82Instead of reading the second half of verse 428, N skips ahead to the second half of verse 429.

83तह जह BN; जह तह ed.

84इअ BN, तो ed.

85साअरेहिं PN; साअरेण JBed.

86वि BN; अ ed.

87पूइअ-रद्द- ed (PJ); पूआ-रइअ- BN.

88ओहुत्तगरुय Jed; उवहुत्तगरुअ B, उहुत्तगरुअ N, अत्थयरिहुंत P.

89विअड-रवि-कणअ ed; मेरुतवणिज्ज N (!).

90वणराइ-तरुगहणं N; रण्णं व वण-गहणं Jed, रन्नं व भुवणयलं B (favored by Upadhye), रत्तं व गयणयलं P.

91उम्मुह-फुरंत ed; पसरिअ-किरंत N.

92सहइ ed; सरइ JN.

93N skips ahead from the first line of 466 to the second line of 467.

94According to Upadhye, B reads verse 475 here instead of this verse.

95एवं ed; एअं NB.

96After the end of 474, N skips ahead to the end of 476 (-वणमहं etc.).

97After मऊह in verse 476, N skips ahead to the same word in verse 477.

98व N; य ed.

99Reading सिणिद्धअं on the basis of B instead.

100No number in P.

101Upadhye was was tempted, as am I, to read भवणमारूढा with B instead of किर समारूढा.

102णडिआण and अंगाण N and B, against ed. तवियाण and अम्हाण.

103अण्णं तं, the reading of N, confirms Upadhye’s conjecture.

104All mss. read सरिसेहिं, but the sense of सरसेहिं is better (so Upadhye).

105Ms. B has a gap of about 20 folios starting from this verse and going up to UPADHYE'S 806.

106In N, तावव ममं पि माहविलआे सिट्ठो कुमार is crossed out.

107लोअवअणाण N; लोवयणाण PJ, लोहवयणाण conj. Upadhye.

108N reads पिहिह after तुम्हाण and then skips to the beginning verse 522.

109N skips over this verse.

110संकहासत्त-माणसो ed.; संकहाकित्तणेण सो N.

111तामस N; तह सं ed.

112दुद्ध Upadhye; दुट्ठ PJN.

113गुहाहरुत्थाइं Jed; गुहाहरत्थाइं PN.

114सुणिसण्णो N and conj. by Upadhye; सुविसण्णो ed.

115णिज्जइ ed.; णज्जइ N, and presumed by gloss in P.

116दुसहो ed; दुल्लहो N.

117तं सि ed.; तं पि conj. Upadhye (तं N).

118मणयंपि PJ; मणयम्मि conj. Upadhye, भणम्मि N.

119विण्णाणराअ conj. Upadhye; विण्णाणुराय ed, चित्ताणुआअ (for चित्ताणुराअ) N. संवाओ NJ; सब्भावो Ped.

120तओ ed; तए N. P has a note to अंवंम्ह (sic), निसुयं च तुह मए वयणं, which is probably copied from a divergent manuscript of the text.

121तत्तो Ped; तो तं J, ता तं N.

122हिअअं मह मअण-हुअवह-पलित्तं ed; मह हिअअ-विअंभिो-मअणो N.

123समागमुद्दूमिआण Ped; समागमे दूमिआण JN. डज्झउ ed; उज्झउ N.

124जाणसु ed; सवाण N.

125झूरसु conj. Upadhye; रूरसु P, तुझू J, सरसु N.

126परिसरो N; परिअणो ed. कीरउ ed; कीरइ N.

127अम्हारिसिआ N; तुम्हारिसिया ed.

128असावण्णं J; असामण्णं PN.

129॰आरि-वक्खो JNed (with minor variants); रिउ-चक्को P. णाम JNed; जाओ P.

130खग्गमग्गे J; खग्गमग्गं P, सुवणुखगे (= सुअणु-खग्गे) N.

131तरु JNed; बहु P.

132Verses 594, 595, and 596 are only found in manuscript J and are likely spurious.

133मअण ed; काम P.

134Verse 599 is missing from N.

135पोत्त-जीविआहरणा ed.; जीवमुत्तआहरणा (unmetrical) N.

136कंद ed.; पत्त N. तरु ed.; वर N.

137विडव ed., but we must understand विडवि (so Upadhye); विविह N.

138तरणि-कर-णिअरं ed.; रविकिरणा (unmetrical) N.

139N skips from पहा to पेच्छंतो in the next verse.

140इमे दिट्ठे ed.; तुमे दिट्ठे N.

141महुर N and conj. Upadhye; मुहर ed.

142णव ed; वण N. विणोअअं ed; विणासअं (!) N. N breaks this verse into two. Apart from these variants P and J share a number of deficient readings against the better readings of N.

143The scribe of N has skipped from दंसण in this verse to दंसण in the next verse, omitting the material in between.

144जह ed; जइ N.

145हिअअ PN; हिअइ Jed.

146रसाअलं म्ह ed.; रसायलम्ह PJ, रसाअणं च N. P reports a variant reading आलावरसोवलं च पंफदियं, which partially agrees with the reading of N (एमणरसाअणं च पप्फुंदिअं).

147विअ ed; चिअ conj. Upadhye. ॰संभरंतीए NJed; ॰संभवंतीए P.

148॰साआस PN; ॰सूसास Jed. मुह JNed; सुह P.

149पोरत्थिअ॰ is read by PJ (and ed.), but पोरच्छअ॰ N is closer to Hemacandra’s पोरच्छ in Deśīnāmamālā 6.62 (although त्थ and च्छ are very common errors for each other).

150संबज्झइ ed.; संकज्जइ N. दीसइ ed.; ईसइ N.

151N omits this verse.

152सिलिंब Jed. (and Deśīnāmamālā); सिलंब NP. सहस्साइँ ed.; सआइ N.

153णिव्वत्तिओ Ned.; णिज्जत्तिओ PJ. णडिआए ed.; मूढाए N.

154N omits this verse.

155णिव्विच्च ed.; णिव्विंत N.

156पिअअम ed.; पिअसहि N. देव्वो N; देवो ed.

157कह विपरिणमइ ed.; कत्थ परिणामो N.

158>विगअरोसो ed.; गअसिणिणहेवो (?) N.

159N skips from आहवगिआण in this verse to (roughly) सुइरण्णेसण of the next verse.

160B and N have a different second line, which I reconstitute as follows: रमणीअ-मणि-सिलाअल-फुरंत-वणराइ-सोहिल्लं. “an arcade of trees shimmered over the stone ground, dazzling with jewels.”

161Verse 1036 is not in N.

162संगलिस्सामो PN, ॰मिलि॰ B, ॰गमि॰ conj. Upadhye.

163परिअट्ठिओ N, ॰वड्ढि॰ ed. (redundant with पवड्ढंत॰).

164सुढिअ from *śṛthita- “slackened” (see S. Insler, “Prakrit Studies I,” Bulletin d’études indiennes 9 (1991): 93–106).

165गइं J and गइ B is a lectio facilior for गयं P and गअं N; interestingly the latter underlies the Sanskrit commentary’s misunderstanding (“elephant of love”), despite B’s reading.

166अण्णेक्क conj., आणॆक्क ed. This word (meaning “another one”) is common in Apabhramsha. The commentator understandsआणिक्य to be a term of art for sideways lovemaking; I have been unable to corroborate this sense.

167This verse, not found in B or N, has been interpolated from an earlier source. It is found with some variations in Hemacandra’s Chandonuśāsana (1.10), in Dhaneśvara’s Surasundarīcarita (3.245), and in Svayambhū’s Svayambhūchandas ( pūrvabhāga 1.3), where it is attributed to Vamaütta.

Notes to the translation

1Vishnu’s weapon is the disc called Sudarshana. Sudarshana has been deprived of the opportunity of killing the demon Hiranyakashipu, because Vishnu has already killed him, having taken the form of the lion (Narasimha).

2In his embodiment as the dwarf, Vishnu took three steps that spanned the whole universe.

3The boy Krishna’s brother, Balabhadra, once laughed at him for being unable to cross the threshold of a door, despite being a form of the supreme god Vishnu.

4Krishna.

5Shesha is the many-headed serpent who lives in the ocean and on whose coils Vishnu and Lakshmi (Shri) sleep; Vishnu keeps the Kaustubha gem on his chest.

6These actions of Krishna are construed in sequence (yathāsaṃkhyam) with their objects. Krishna uprooted two arjuna trees who were actually two yakshas that had been cursed.

7On Rudra’s (Shiva’s) head are both the Ganges and the crescent moon.

8The commentator explains that people have a higher tolerance for faults if they believe the author is a good person.

9The three holy Vedas: the Ṛgveda, the Yajurveda, and Sāmaveda. The three sacred fires: the domestic (gārhapatya), eastern (āhavanīya), and southern (dakṣiṇa). Three aims of life: doing what is right (dharma), power (artha), and pleasure (kāma).

10rays: The word kara- can mean both “paw” and “ray.”

11pearls of rut: Hardened secretions from the temples of rutting elephants are called “pearls” (muttāhala-) by poetic convention.

12rasa: This key term, which I generally leave untranslated, bridges the semantics of taste (it can refer to the “taste” of a food or drink) and of aesthetics (it can refer to an emotional response to a work of art).

13the girls of the ten directions: the ten directions (the four cardinal directions, the four intermediate directions, and the zenith and nadir) are often figured as young women. Here the swaying of trees is compared to the designs painted on their faces (viśeṣika). See Subhāṣitaratnakośa 196 for a similar image.

14cakravāka birds (ruddy shell drakes): by poetic convention, pairs of these birds are separated during the night and reunited during the day. Here the moonlight deceives them into thinking that it is day.

15lily-eyed: the author addresses his wife throughout the story with epithets such as this (kuvalaadalacchi ‘whose eyes are like the petals of a waterlily’; ubbiṃbabālahariṇacchi ‘whose eyes are like those of a frightened fawn’; etc.).

16Anandavardhana in his Dhvanyāloka has reproduced this classification (and cited the Līlāvaī as an example of the “divine-human” type). Probably earlier than the Līlāvaī is Haribhadra’s Samarāiccakahā, which also relates this classification.

17the boar: when the earth was dragged down to the bottom of the ocean by a demon, Vishnu took the form of a boar, slew the demon, and raised the earth back up. There is a pun ongaruabhāvāe, which means “solemnity” (in the case of her contact with the god Vishnu) and “weight” (in the case of the gems she acquired while at the bottom of the ocean).

18of pleasant lodging: suvvasia does not mean “well-settled” but “pleasant to stay in” (a reference to the pleasures that await travellers, much celebrated in Prakrit poetry of the Sattasaī, rather than the foresight of village planners).

19 carcarī-songs : a particular kind of song accompanied by a dance. See H. C. Bhayani, “Some Specimens of the Carcarī Song”, Sambodhi 1(1): 1972, 15–27 = pp. 34–53 in Indological Studies: Literary and Performing Arts, Prakrit and Apabhraṁśa Studies (Volume 1), Ahmedabad: Parshva Prakashan, 1993.

20golden age: the kṛta-yuga is the first of four mythical “ages” (the others are the treta-, dvāpāra-, and kali-yugas) which are characterized by successive moral decay.

21the creator’s template: sikkhaṭṭhāṇaṃ, “place of instruction.” The idea is that Ashmaka was the template from which the creator (Prajapati) copied as he learned how to create the rest of the world.

22After this verse, the text breaks into rhythmic prose. A.N. Upadhye, with the help of H.D. Velankar, has tried to identify portions of verse-forms here (see ed. p. 335–336).

23social orders: the division of society into four distinct orders or varṇas (brāhmaṇas, kṣatriyas, vaiśyas, and śūdras).

24age of wickedness: the kaliyuga, the last and most morally degraded of the four ages (and the present age).

25The three adjectives in this verse each have two meanings (a figure called śleṣa), one that applies to the rivers and another that applies to the women.

26moonstone: the candrakānta or candramaṇi, a gem said to be formed from the moon’s rays;

27smoke-blackened sky: according to poetic convention, peacocks dance at the onset of the monsoon season; the peacocks mistake the smoke rising from sacrificial fires for monsoon clouds.

28women with midnight appointments: the abhisārikā, a woman who goes out at night to meet a lover, requires the anonymity of darkness, but the houses in Pratishthana are lit with jewel-lamps (for gharamaṇi in the sense of “lamp” see Setubandha 10.52 and Rāmadāsa ad loc.). The commentator imagines that the light pours into the streets because the walls of the houses are made of crystal, as noted in verse 65 below.

29Women washing turmeric off of their bodies—particularly Maharashtrian women in the Godavari river—is a motif of Prakrit literature: see Sattasaī W58, which the present verse echoes (ajjea haliddāpiṃjarāi golāi tūhāiṃ).

30The idea seems to be that the scent of jasmine itself resolves any quarrels between lovers.

31This text refers to the king as both Sātavāhana (Prakrit sālāhaṇa) or Hāla.

32The figure is apparent contradiction (virodhābhāsa). The word aviggaha can mean “without corporeal form” or, resolving the contradiction, “without war” (because all of his enemies have been conquered); duddaṃsaṇa can mean “terrible to look upon” or, resolving the contradiction, “difficult to look upon” (because of his overpowering brilliance, according to the commentary).

33Another apparent contradiction (virodhābhāsa). Kupati means “a bad husband” or (resolving the contradiction) “the lord of the earth”; ṇaavaro means “one whose enemies are bowed down” or (resolving the contradiction) “devoted to good policy.” For the second half, the commentary suggests that the contradictory meaning is “although afraid of the world beyond, he delighted in acts of heroism,” and the resolved meaning is “because he was concerned for the world beyond, he delighted in religious acts.”

34The figure is once again apparent contradiction; here I have rendered the resolved meaning after the dash.

35The two adjectives in this sentence can be read differently to apply to both the moon and the king.

36According to a poetic convention, the plants (osahi) that grow in mountain-caves give off a reddish light at night.

37This verse probably refers to Hāla’s reputation as a patron of literature. The first chapter of Kathāsaritsāgara, for example, revolves around Guṇāḍhya’s efforts to have Hāla-Sātavāhana publish his story (the mythical Bṛhatkathā).

38The god of love (Kāmadeva) is represented with a bow and arrow made out of flowers.

39ornament on his forehead: the word tilaa can refer to a forehead-ornament or a type of plant (sesame).

40Upadhye notes that the custom of wearing red garments on a wedding day is mentioned also by Haribhadra in his Samarāiccakahā.

41Here the wind is figured as an unfaithful lover (parimala can refer to both fragrance and sexual union).

42The samāgama-tthāṇa or saṃketa-sthāna is a secret place where lovers agree to meet. It is a common motif in Prakrit poetry.

43The golden mountain is Meru, thought to occupy the center of the universe. The directions are usually figured as young women (see note to verse 30 above).

44bedroom: The idea is that the sky is suffused with pollen in the same way that a living space is suffused with incense or perfumes.

45The following verses (99–104) describe the designs painted onto a courtesan’s body.

46paths: Nimkar translates as “scars.”

47Note the alliteration of the Prakrit: pattattaṃ pattaṃ patta-lacchi pattaṃ.

48realist style: viddha refers to a realistic mode of representation in painting (see V. Raghavan’s discussion in “Sanskrit Texts on Painting,” Indian Historical Quarterly 9.4 (1933): 898–911.

49Spring festival: the maaṇa-mahūsava.

50public discussion: the goṭṭhī is a meeting of poets and scholars at a royal court, and involves public recitation of poetry (and on-the-spot composition of poems), critical evaluation, and so on.

51in this way: as artists.

52Yakshas: Yakshas are a race of demigods, dwarfish in stature, who are often represented as guards or protective deities. The commentary explains that spies are called Yakshas because (like Yakshas) they know how to disguise themselves. Upadhye suggests that this remark has a double meaning: ṇaresa- could mean “snake charmer” in addition to “king,” and kaḍaa- could mean (a snake charmer’s) “ring” in addition to “court” (were snake-charmers also called Yakshas)?

53rulers over large territories: mahāmaṃḍalāhivā. The Arthaśāstra presents a theory of kingship based on the maṇḍala or territorial circle.

54festival: the word caccarī primarily refers to the dance performed at springtime festivals, but here it refers to the whole festival.

55household priest: purohia, the priest who performs the king’s domestic rituals.

56daily allowance: I take ṇicca-ṇivesia to be the gifts that the king gives to Brahmins on a daily basis.

57officers: bhoa on my understanding refers to a particular type of feudal lord.

58secretive chatter: the commentary understands by saṇṇā the in-group codes such as mūladevī and karapallavī, which operate by a transposition of sounds, much like “pig Latin.” The word could simply mean “hand signals.”

59Bhatta Kumarila’s feet: the commentary explains that Vijayananda, in his current state, is unfit to look upon the king himself.

60approached: although the commentary gives the meaning “embrace,” Prakrit lexicons define the root aïcch- as “to go.”

61full of wishes that remain unfulfilled: literally, “a source of good desires.” The implication is that the various relationships described in Vijayananda’s story await their fulfillment.

62Malaya: the southern mountains, more or less equivalent to Kerala today.

63Pandya: one of the ancient Tamil kingdoms, centered in Madurai.

64texts on polity: attha-satthehiṃ, an example of which is the eponymous Arthaśāstra ascribed to Kauṭilya.

65great lord: the title paramesara suggests that king Satavahana is a worshipper of Shiva, which is confirmed repeatedly in the text.

66The figure here is paradox (virodhābhāsa), which in each case is resolved by reading one of the words in a secondary meaning: instead of “beautiful women overrun it,” we understand “Rama leaped over it”; instead of “full of poison,” “full of water”; and instead of “protect the great king Indra,” “protect the mountain ranges.” Two mythological events are referenced here: Shiva’s churning of the ocean, from which emerged the heavenly nymphs, the cosmic poison, the horse Uccaihshravas, and the elephant Airavana; and Rama’s crossing of the ocean to get to Lanka.

67Again the figure is virodhābhāsa. Compare Setubandha 2.18: “Even though restless, it remained steadfast by respecting its limits. It abounded in riches, even though its treatures had been taken out by the gods (during the churning). It was unscathed, even though churned; and oozed nectar, even though its waters had a briny taste.” caḍulaṃ pi thiīa thiraṃ tiasukkhitta-raaṇaṃ pi sārabbhahiaṃ | mahiaṃ pi aṇoluggaṃ asāu-salilaṃ pi amaa-rasa-ṇīsaṃdaṃ ||

68The monkey king, Sugriva, helped Rama get to Lanka by having his army build a bridge across the ocean.

69According to literary convention, the flowers of the saptaparṇa tree smell like rutting elephants.

70siddhas: In this story, the siddhas (literally “perfected ones”) are human-like beings with magical powers who inhabit the southern mountains.

71Rameshwara: a shrine, now the site of a twelfth-century temple, at the tip of South India where Rama is believed to have crossed the ocean to Lanka.

72Here the apparent contradiction (virodhābhāsa; see note to verse 169) takes the form of a riddle: once we know that these adjectives qualify the word “ship” (bohitthe), we must re-read them all to yield a suitable meaning.

73Kali age: Kali is the last and present of the four ages, or yugas, associated with moral impurity and the decay of the social order.

74Love in bodily form: Shiva incinerated the body of Love (Kama), who was henceforth known as “the incorporeal” (anaṅga).

75Triad: trayī usually means the three Vedas, but it must mean something else here (the commentary in B says the past, present, and future; the gloss in P says accomplished, fully accomplished, and still to be accomplished).

76rudrākṣa: devotees of Shiva wear strings of these dry red seeds, like a rosary.

77lord of the day: the sun.

78forest-goddess: vaṇasaī, uncertain.

79puṇya: merit accumulated in past lives, held to be the cause of success or luck in the present life.

80Yaksha: a race of semi-human beings associated with lakes and forests.

81śālabhañjikā: a common sculptural motif in Indian temple architecture, in which a woman stands next to a śāla tree and attempts to break (bhañj-) its branches.

82bull-pavilion: probably the part of the temple that housed an image of Shiva’s mount (vāhana), the bull. (In this text, the bull is clearly distinguished from Nandi.) We might imagine something like the life-size bull sculpture now housed in the Amaravati Museum.

83towers: I take tavaṃga in this sense; it is not listed in the lexicons.

84woody vines: māhavi-laā, the vines of Hiptage benghalensis.

85welcome-offering: aggho, an offering presented to a guest upon arrival, usually consisting of water with flower-petals in it.

86thousand eyes: Indra is sometimes said to have a thousand eyes after an incident in which he attempted to seduce Ahalya, the wife of the sage Gautama, and Gautama cursed him to be covered in a thousand vaginas, which were later changed into eyes.

87unblinking gaze: the gods are traditionally said to be animiṣa, “without blinking.”

88bark garments: ascetics usually wear clothes made out of tree bark (valkala).

89Fame and Prosperity: Fame (kittī) and Prosperity (or Lakshmi, here called kamalā) are both personified as women, and both are traditionally white. The idea is that Mahanumati and Kuvalayavali’s bark garments make them look as white as Fame and Prosperity personified.

90when it was churned: Lakshmi was one of the products of the mythical “churning of the ocean of milk,” which the gods undertook in order to produce the nectar of immortality (amṛta).

91The ocean is often figured as a repository of jewels (ratnākara); here Vijayananda is described as a repository of virtues.

92The commentary explains “pure” (suī) as “of pure descent on both his mother’s and father’s sides.”

93The sense provided by sa ccia bhūmī suhehiṁ saccaviā is not quite satisfactory; the idea is that the two girls agree to host Vijayananda because he is a guest of the hermit, and hence wherever he stays is equal in estimation to the whole world.

94Mahanumati addresses Vijayananda as bhaṭṭaütta, literally “son of a learned man.”

95set aside formality: the commentary understands the phrase parisaṃṭhia-vesaṃbhaṃ as “with increased familiarity”; it seems, rather, to be an idiomatic expression such as “letting loose.”

96bewildered: I follow Upadhye’s suggestion of taking paṇaṭṭha-sumaraṇā (literally “because of my disturbed sense of recollection”) as an ablative of cause.

97Family Mountains: the kula-parvatas are the seven principal mountain ranges in traditional Indian cosmology, although according to many sources, Meru is not included in this list: the 17th chapter of Rājaśekhara’s Kāvyamīmāṃsā, for example, lists Mahendra, Malaya, Sahya, Pariyātra, Śuktimān, Vindhya, and Ṛkṣa. These verses (281–288) present a description of Mount Meru that forms a single syntactic unit in Prakrit (a kulaka); it bears close comparison with the famous kulaka that describes Mount Himalaya in the beginning of Kālidāsa’s Kumārasaṃbhava (1.1–17).

98ruddy elephants of the horizon: the cardinal directions are often figured as elephants. In this verse, the red-orange color of the elephants is likened to the color of the gold-dust on Mount Meru, which Shiva’s bull is conventionally said to dig up.

99Kinnaras: another race of semidivine beings, usually depicted with a human body and a horse’s face. The reading adopted here, mārua, refers to a type of deer (the vātaprami, according to the commentator); Upadhye’s reading would refer to the Kinnaras drinking spiritous liquor (māhava).

100Tumbura: a mythical musician (Gandharva). improvising a tune: ālatti, which Sanskrit sources on music (e.g., the Saṅgītaratnākara) define as an improvised tune that precedes the performance of a musical composition. Brahma’s goose: Brahma’s mount is the goose.

101pārijāta: the pārijāta tree is a mythical tree said to exist in Indra’s heaven. slows them down: such is the sense I’ve extracted from maüia-pahammi “on a path softened (i.e., slowed) by…”; the reading implied by the commentary (muia-hiaāhi “with hearts gladdened by…”) might be better.

102Airavana: Indra’s mythical elephant. The ichor (masth) that flows out of a rutting elephant’s temples is a common subject in kāvya.

103Vidyadharas: another race of semidivine beings, endowed with magical powers (vidyās).

104Vasantashri means “Spring Beauty,” and Sharadashri means “Autumn Beauty.”

105Verses 294 to 298 are a syntactically-unified description of Ganesh’s dance.

106great serpents: probably the snakes that Shiva wears around his neck.

107to whose mouths: “those whose mouths smell of milk” is taken to mean “young girls” by the commentary; Upadhye suggests that “milk was the primary food of girls till they reached their age.”

108The mountain is so high that the sun’s light only reaches its base.

109submarine file: in Indian cosmology, a fire (called Vaḍavā) was thought to burn in the depths of the ocean.

110serpents: according to a poetic convention, sandal trees are often inhabited by dangerous snakes. The implication is that the sandal trees are close to the sun because of Mount Malaya’s elevation.

111dried up: because the grass and the ground are the same green color, the grass is only conspicuous when it dries up and turns yellow-brown.

112cleansed: viccholia could also mean “shivering”.

113The following three verses (361–363) form a “chain composition” (śṛṅkhala-bandha), in which the last word of each line is reprised in the beginning of the next line.

114An image of the God of Love was sometimes installed at the base of an Ashoka tree and worshipped during certain festivals (see Harṣa’s Ratnāvalī.

115Rati: the wife of the God of Love (kāmadeva, manmatha, anaṅga) is called Rati, sexual pleasure personified.

116forest-goddess: vaṇa-sirī, the personification of the beauty (śrī) of the forest.

117offerings of your lotus-feet: lotus petals are a typical offering (upacāra) in temples.

118intricate designs: This is one guess for the difficult phrase patta-vicchitti-palahuo; the following verses also present difficulties.

119stand: the sara-jaṃta- is a folding stand whose legs are similar to arrows.

120whose strength is unsurpassed: there is a shade of double-meaning here, since thāmo can mean both “strength” and “position”; Mount Meru can never be moved from its place.

121this life of ours: Madhavilata refers to herself in the plural, as is common for women in this story (the commentator suggests on verse 392 that the poet consistently uses the plural out of respect).

122an image of the God of Love: Upadhye reasonably speculates that chaṇa-vammaha refers to the image of the God of Love that was worshipped during the spring festival.

123There is an obvious double-meaning in verse 390, according to which several words could be construed as referring to either playing on a swing or having sex (particularly the root ram-, which occurs three times in the verse).

124The ground, which is red, is figured as having received its red color from the soles of Kuvalayavali’s feet, which are painted with lac.

125I follow Upadhye’s suggestion that saṃgalaṇa comes from Sanskrit saṃkalana, “heaping together.”

126Sister: Prakrit has a large number of terms of address among female friends.

127liquefied: because she Mahanumati started to sweat profusely.

128The sense of 434 is clear, but Mahanumati’s request probably involves a colloquial sense of saccavijjāsu, which would normally mean “look” (although the meaning “fix one’s attention on” might be original: see Herman Tieken, “Hāla’s Sattasaī as a Source of Pseudo-Deśī Words,” Bulletin d’études indiennes 10 [1992]: 221–267).

129The use of the first person plural in reference to a singular speaker is common in Prakrit.

130like a garment slipping down: rendering the pun on vialiaṃsu.

131The figure of “corroboration” (arthāntaranyāsa) is enhanced by the condensed expression (samāsokti) in the words “position” (both physical and social) and “obscurity” (both darkness and loss of face). Upadhye takes laṃghio as “insulted” and suggests a different meaning: at evening, as opposed to noon, the sun is weak enough to be looked upon—and thus insulted—by men.

132As in the previous verse, we have “condensed expression,” this time involving the words sūro (sun and hero) and pacchimāe (western and final). The idea is that a dying hero is carried by his comrades.

133Chakravaka birds: Ruddy shelducks are said to be separated from their mates by night.

134Upadhye draws our attention to a similar simile in the Slaying of the Gauḍa King (Gaüḍavaho), v. 1115.

135As vasuāa typically means “dried,” I understand the reference to be a saffron flower, which is typically deep blue, that has become pale upon drying out. Upadhye offers the (to my mind unlikely) alternative that vasuāa means “dew” (cf. Sanskrit avaśyāya) and hence the simile compares the night’s face to a crocus covered in dew.

136According to poetic convention, sandalwood trees are inhabited by snakes, and there are plants, often imagined to grow in caves, that have their own luminescence.

137submarine fire: the fire that is imagined to burn beneath the ocean.

138I present and translate N’s text, which offers a superior sense.

139On B’s reading, the flag is flying ahead of the moon’s house rather than his chariot.

140displaced: I follow Nimkar’s suggestion as to this slightly obscure verse.

141The Vindya mountains are dark (because of their Khadira trees, see v. ) but have light streaks because of their waterfalls.

142women who steal away at night: to meet their lovers. These women are called abhisārikās.

143treetop: without construing sihara as “treetop” it is difficult to fit this phrase into the simile.

144deadly: literally, “as dangerous as poison”.

145Mahanumati’s chest could be red as lotus pollen (the redness happening because of her fever), or red from lotus pollen (which is applied, like sandalwood paste, as a cooling remedy).

146There are textual problems with this verse; I follow Upadhye’s suggestion.

147I follow Nimkar’s understanding of this verse.

148Verse 523 is difficult for me to understand, as it should be addressed to Mahanumati rather than Kuvalayavali.

149paritaliṇa usually means “very thin,” but Upadhye (and Nimkar following him) tentatively understands it as “gathered at the bottom.”

150There is a double-meaning, with āsāmukha referring to the distinct “faces” of the directions (which are indistinguishable at night) and containing the word for “hope,” and loa referring to “light” and “people.”

151The adjectives in 536 all have a double meaning, referring to qualities of the moon and to an ideal lover.

152encourage each other: literally “make their hearts.”

153think about them endlessly: a pun on the word guṇa, “good quality,” which also has the sense of multiplication.

154the seventh rasa: there are broadly two conceptions of rasa in traditional Indian thought. The first is equivalent to “taste,” and six such tastes are enumerated. The second is an emotional that is realized in literary or dramatic art, and eight or nine such emotions are enumerated. Interestingly, it is the first classification and not the second that stands in the background of Madhavilata’s comment. This verse is quoted in the Subhāsiyagāhāsaṃgaho (v. 117).

155This verse, like the last, is quoted in the Subhāsiyagāhāsaṃgaho (v. 118).

156Upadhye notes that a verse nearly identical to 577 occurs in the Agaḍadatta story in Devendra’s commentary (1123) to a canonical Jain text, the Uttarādhyayana Sūtra.

157This verse is quoted in Subhāsiyagāhāsaṃgaho v. 121.

158that goes against your birth: translating J’s asāvaṇṇaṃ (a-sāvarṇya) “contrary to the principle of marrying within one’s caste”; the reading of P and N, asāmaṇṇaṃ, simply means “strange.”

159This verse presents a number of difficulties.

160sustained myself like a young animal: I understand āharaṇa to derive from ādharaṇa (unattested in Sanskrit) rather than ābharaṇa, and potta in the sense of pota (the young of a plant or animal).

161The last sentence of verse 632 is not clear: Upadhye suggests that “she means to say that any girl would very much like the idea of being lovingly looked at by him.”

162I take avasārio from avasāritaḥ and not, as Upadhye would have it (following the gloss in manuscript P), from aprasāritaḥ.

163A svayaṃvara is an event at which the woman selects her own husband, usually on the basis of some feat of strength.

164from the netherworld: the usual meaning of the postposition samaaṃ in Prakrit is “together with,” but the image here requires the sense “from” (as Upadhye’s Sanskrit translation suggests); both meanings are common in the later language (cf. Hindi se). breach: so Nimkar.

165The Buddhist monk Nagarjuna, one of the key figures in the development of Mahayana Buddhism, was contemporaneous by a king of the Satavahana dynasty (probably Shriyajna in the late 2nd c. CE). Here, the memory of that Nagarjuna, who is also reputed to have visited the world of the Nagas, is conflated with the memory of an powerful alchemist (siddha) who entered the historical record several centuries later.

166righteousness, pleasure, or liberation: dharma, kāma, and mokṣa; three of the four commonly-accepted goals of human life (the last is artha, power).

167enjoyments: Patala, the subterranean realm of the Nagas, is associated with bhoga, which means “enjoyment” of pleasure as well as the “hood” of a snake. This verse probably contains a veiled reference to the eight magical powers (aṣṭasiddhis) of the siddhas.

168a few miles: literally, half a yojana (a measure of distance roughly equivalent to six miles).

169Heramba: Ganesha, the leader of Shiva’s hosts (gaṇas).

170Bhava: Shiva.

171The supports of kingship (sthāna) are army, treasury, city, territory (commentators to Manusmṛti 7.56).

172Several of the words in this verse are obscure.

173This verse refers to two dynasties which held power in central India in the later first millennium, and which were probably contemporary with the author (since neither dynasty was contemporary with the Satavahanas). The Solankis (here sulaṃkī-) are known in Sanskrit sources as Chalukyas.

174This section (1073–1873) form a “set piece” about the love affairs of anonymous men and women. This topos dates to at least the 5th century, when Pravarasena included such an episode in hisSetubandha, but it is thematically connected to the erotic poetry of the earlier Sattasaī. For some of these difficult verses, my interpretation is provisional; the published literature needs to be surveyed for comparanda.

175Cheeks smeared with red ghee indicates that a woman is having her period.

176Manmatha: the god of love. His emotion (rasa) is the erotic (śṛṅgāra).

177Nearly all of the words in verses 1081–1084 (which constitute a syntactic unit) are complex adjectives describing the sexual encounters (mohaṇāiṃ) of the couples, that is, their affairs.

178saṃ-mil- “to shut” hererefers to both flowers and eyes.

179ṇihasa- is to be taken from nikaṣa- “rubbing.”
